Inline withthe approach developedthrough consultations with countries anddonors, thisproject will focus on areaso flocust control andpreventionwhere the World Bank has a comparative advantage: (i) provision o f quick financial assistance for the imports necessary for control operations, (ii) reconstruction activities (restoring productive assets andproviding bridgingincome-earning activities), and (iii) assistance to improve the early warning, mobilization, andmitigation systems. Objectives 2. The project aims to helpreduce the hardships imposedon people andthe environment by current and future locust invasions. These hardshipsnot only include the immediate effects o f crop and livestock losses, but also delayed effects from lost productive assets andreduced income opportunities. It i s the rural poor who suffer most from the effects locust infestation. The risks posed to people andthe environment from application, handling, andstorage o fpesticides are equally significant. 3. The project will also seek to reduce the vulnerability o fthe concerned countries to future infestationsby supportingimproved strategies for prevention, early warning, reaction, andmitigation at boththe national and regional levels. Regional collective action is required to respondto this regional plague. 4. The project (i) on the Bank's areas o f comparative advantage inproviding focuses financing at the country level for activities that will complement funds committedby other donors for regional initiatives, and (ii) buildsupon existing World Bank and operations inthe region inorder to respond quickly to the crisis. 5. The ProjectDevelopmentObjective(PDO) i s to reduce the vulnerability o f the concerned countries to future infestationsby supporting improved strategies for prevention, early warning, reaction, andmitigation, at boththe national andregional levels. This will be achieved by (i) helping countries to controllmanage locust infestations, (ii)mitigating the effects o f locust infestations on people andthe environment, and (iii) helpingto ensure amore timely reactionto future infestations in Chad, Niger, Burkina Faso, Mali, Mauritania, Senegal, and The Gambia. Project Components 6. The project will include a number o f emergency activities, post-emergency recovery activities, and activities to improve future preparedness. These activities have been organized into four components:
Component A: Emergency Locust Management 7. This component includes investments for the emergency actions requiredto ensure that locust management activities are timely, cost-effective, and environmentally and socially sustainable. Two types o f activities will be supported inthis component: (i) an emergency locust campaign required to manage any current or resurgent infestations, and (ii) inventoriesofpesticidesandevaluationofpesticidestorageareastoensure detailed
1  effective management after the crisis, includingupgrade o f storage areas, and if necessary, preparation for disposal o f any obsolete pesticides inthe country. Component B: Emergency Agriculture Investments 8. This component includes investments for the emergency actions requiredto restore agricultural productivity inpriority rural areas that were damaged by locusts. Investments to be provided include provision o f `starter packs' (seeds, fertilizers, tools) and animal feed to rural populations, andmay also includejob creation for those who have lost cropshncome due to locust infestation. Suchjobs will be created through existing community-driven development or social projects and could include small-scale local civil works. Financing o f activities under this component will complement that o f other donors andwill be within the framework o fthe needs expressed by FAO, WFP, and CILSS. Component C: Early Warning and Response 9. This component includes medium- andlong-term activities requiredto strengthen the national capacity for early warning andresponse to outbreaks. World Bank financing o f activities inthis component will complement investments made by the European Commission andthe African Development Bank for the EMPRESprogram initiatedby FAO. Investments will be made inthree areas: (i) strengtheningthe early warning system procedures (capacity o f crop protection agencies), (ii) equipment, sohare, andother goods requiredto operationalizethe system, and(iii) awareness campaign and mobilization of village brigades for early warning. Component D: Project Management 10. The output o fthis component will be effective project management (which is, designed, adjusted, monitored, andevaluated to reflect changing conditions) that would be able to address potentially shiftingrequirements andpriorities o f the effort to help manage locust infestations, as well as their effects on people and the environment inthe concerned countries. Activities with Regional Scope 11. There are three areas o fintervention that warrant a regional approach - coordination o f locust control, research into alternatives to chemical control measures, and monitoring and evaluation. Such activities will be financed through specific earmarked allocations inthe country projects. The coordination o f the regional work would take place at annual meetings o f countries participating inthis project, or at other relevant events such as sessions o f CLCPRO. Background.Breedingandmigrationpatterns o fdesert locusts cover some 28 million sq. km and 65 countries inAfrica, the Middle East, and Southwest Asia. Since 1860, there havebeen ten major upsurges o f desert locusts inthese areas. Organized crop protection campaigns against locusts began inthe early 1900s. Duringthe 1 9 5 0 FA0 ~ ~ established regional sub-committees for each o f the important geopolitical regions associatedwith desert locust migrations (Northwest Africa, Near East and Southwest Asia). These evolved into FA0Regional Commissions concerned primarily with the coordination of joint surveys, control, training, andresearchbymember states. Member states finance activities unilaterally andthrough contributions to a trust h d , set their own policies, anddetermine survey and control activities. 17. Intandem with FAO's initiatives, autonomous regional organizations for locust control also emerged, initially as offshoots o f earlier colonial structures. InEast Africa, the Desert Locust Control Organization for Eastern Africa (DLCO-EA) was created with a mandate to address all migratory pests, with emphasis onbackstoppingheinforcingthe locust control capacity o f its member states (Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, Sudan, Tanzania, andUganda). InWest Africa, the mandate o fthe Organisation Commune de LutteAntiacridienne (OCLA), established in 1958, was expanded to address migratory insect and avian pests (OCLALAV), however, OCLALAV's operationalmandate reverted to its member states in 1989, leaving a void interms of collective decision-making and action at the regional level. In recent years, CILSS (Commit6 Inter-Etat pour la Lutte contre la Secheresse dans le Sahel), which is charged with fightingdrought inthe Sahel andalso mandated to provide technical support and training inplant protection (including registration o fpesticides), has provided meteorological information andvegetation data andrelatedmaps through its AGRHYMETdepartment (Agriculture, Hydrology andMeteorology). 18. PresentGlobalandRegionalCoordinationMechanism.At the international level, the Desert Locust Control Committee (DLCC), which was established in 1952, includes 65 countries and is hostedby FAO. It leads the technical discussions about locust management. The DLCC created the Emergency Center for Locust Operations (ECLO) andthree regional commissions, including CLCPRO (Commission de luttecontre le criquet pblerin dans la r6gion Occidentale [Commission for Controlling the Desert Locust inthe Western Region]) incharge ofcoordinating locust operations innine frontline countries o fNorth and West Africa. In 1994, FA0 also launched the Emergency Prevention System (EMPRES) for Trans-boundary Animal and Plant Pests andDiseases. 19. EmergencyCenter for LocustOperations(ECLO). InAugust 2004, FA0re- established ECLO based at FA0headquarters inorder to strengthen its response to the locust upsurge.ECLO continually monitors the locust situation andi s the focal point for assistance to locust-affected countries. 20. ECLO works closely with CLCPRO, which i s responsible for coordination o f locust activities innine front-line countries. 21. ECLO maintains a regular dialogue with the international donor community. Priorities for assistance are based on information provided almost every day bynational locust control units andplantprotection services, supplemented by reports from FAO's

ECLO also collects bilateral assistance inorder to coordinate inputs and avoid duplicate efforts. 22. EmergencyPreventionSystem.When EMPRES (Emergency Prevention System for Trans-boundary Animal andPlant Pests and Diseases) was founded in 1994, initial priority was given to trans-boundary pest and disease problems. The desert locust is a big component o f EMPRES because it i s considered a serious and large-scale threat to agricultural production inAfrica. Its frequent swarmmigrations across borders often require large-scale regional control operations. EMPRES i s structured byregion covering the western region (EMPRES-RO), the centralregion (EMPRES-RC) andthe eastern region (EMPRES-ER). 23. This commissionpromotes, at the national, regional, andinternational levels, action, research, and training to ensure prevention of, and appropriate response to, the invasions o f desert locust inthe western region o f its distribution area, Northwest and West Africa. 24. The western region o f the invasion area includes Algeria, Chad, Libya, Mali, Morocco, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, andTunisia, countries inwhich the locust behaves gregariously or that are directly affectedby all early upsurges. CLCPRO is hostedby the Algeriangovernment inAlgiers andrepresents the central forum for locust management today. RootCauses of DesertLocustInvasions 25. There is a consensus among experts andmajor actors on the key factors that have led to the present locust emergency. Principal among these is the lack o fpreparedness at the national, regional and international levels. The failure o f the affected countries andtheir partnersto maintain a minimalcapacity duringthe longremissionphaseshas resultedina weakened system unable to respond ina timely fashion to prevent the current upsurge. The organizations and mechanisms for regional coordination are limited to a consultative role and do not have the operational function that is desperately needed for trans- boundary actions -regional mobilization andpooling o f resources to provide a timely response where andwhen needed. 26. At the international level, mobilization o fthe necessary funds has beentoo slow to be effective. Donor interest inlong-term development goals o f locust management has tended to vary with the situation andwere very low duringthe recession period o f 1994 to 2004. The EMPRES project didnot have sufficient funds, OCLALAV was not operational, anduntilthe crisis became significantly aggravated toward June and July, donor contributions were limited despite numerous appeals by FAO. Another important issue to note i s that the rationale for triggering control operations has not always based on realistic assessmentso f risks, but rather insome cases on political considerations. In summary, the present systemis too dependent on donors, with a serious lack o flong-term commitment duringremission phases.

Project Strategy 28. Inorder to create a sound and sustainable locust management program, the project favors a strategy based on ecologicalprinciples and IntegratedPest Management (IPM). Actions need to be targeted at the national, regional, and international levels. The project strategy will include:
0 Efficient monitoring and surveillance systems staffedbywell-trained andwell- equippednational teams to monitor, assess risks, andtrigger early warnings. The early warnings need to be translated into actions that will trigger a well-articulated emergency planfor rapid response incase o f an upsurge. 0 A regional coordinationentity that is legally autonomous, owned andempowered by member countries, with an adequatemandate, operatingpolicies, fimdingmechanism, and the necessary human and financial resources to coordinate local andtrans- boundary efforts with the active participation o f affectednational programs. 0 A regionayinternational fundingmechanismable to mobilize the resources neededto control outbreaks ina timely fashion andpotentially fundnecessary post-disaster mitigation activities to support affected populations andrebuild productive assets.
, 29. The project aims to strengthen the capacity o fnational programs to meet the necessary requirements for an efficient monitoring and surveillance system at the national level. The project recommends a complete review or audit o fthe existingregional systems for locust monitoring andcontrol. Theproposedreview will address technical, institutional, operational, regulatory, and financial capacities, including identificationo f sustainable risks and cost-sharing mechanisms by interested countries to maintain minimal and operational expertise. Inconsultation with CLCPROmember countries, a panelo fexperts will initiatethe review andmakerecommendations to advance the strategic framework for strong nationalprograms and an efficient andoperational regional network. The review panel should strive to identify constraints impeding establishment o f long-term risk andcost-sharing mechanisms, related national and regionalpolicies, and the supporting and complementary role o f the donor community. 30. It i s clear that not all countries canjustify a long-term investment ina national locust program, but establishment o f a regional network could play a crucial role indeveloping improvedpolicies, early warning systems, contingency plans, and control strategies linked to environmental impact assessments. However, the sustainability o f such a regionalnetwork hinges on the commitment o fmember countries to long-term financing through cost sharing, complementedwith a sound fimdraising strategy and an international andor regional `emergency fimd' or calamity insurance for severe cases, be it locusts or birdinfestationsor drought.

Indeed, there are no reliable estimates o f (i) magnitude o fthe the actual and projectedinfestations andtheir impact onproduction and affectedpopulations; and (ii)the cost to eradicate the infestationor measures to mitigate its impact. Estimated project costs include important physical contingencies, and project activities will need to beadjusted onthe basis o factual needs anddevelopments onthe ground (as trackedby the M&Esystem that willbe established at the beginningofthe program). Thus, only a general qualitative discussion i s presented below. 32. The potential benefits o fthe project (the losses avoided as a result o fthe project) fall into three main categories:
0 benefits o f the proposed emergency control and eradication measures; 0 benefits o f the proposed strengthening o f countries' surveillance andprevention capacities; and 0 benefits from the proposedmeasures to provide assistanceto the affectedpopulations. These three main categories are discussed intuminthe paragraphs below.
EconomicJustificationof ControlMeasures 33. The potential benefits o f control measures are the losses that will be avoided. Future losses depend on the likelihood andmagnitude of new outbreaks that cannot be determinedwith any degree o f certainty. Inaddition, should they occur, their impact on the vegetative cover is very difficult to estimate. Indeed, physical (andmonetary) estimates are very difficult to obtain. Because o fthe nature o f the swarms, losses are unevenly distributed inspace andtime, even within affected areas. Where swarms do not land, losses do not occur. Where swarms do land, however, losses canbe total within hours at the local level. The level o f losses is also highly dependent on a number o f variables, including the number o f insects, how long they stay inthe area, plant species, and the stage o f crop development. Interms o f control strategies, the efficacy, efficiency, and equitability o f locust control programs are undocumented or rely largely on anecdotal information. While insecticides undoubtedlykillinsects and canprotect standing crops, their ability to end or prevent plagues is not clear. 34. Despite all these limitations, a crude costbenefit analysis can be attempted to provide roughjustification for proposedcontrol measures. The cost o f spraying a hectare has been estimated at US$15. The average price o f a ton o f cereal i s about US$140. If the average cereal productivity were 1ton/ha (which i s close to the world average in2000), then the costbenefit ratio would be about 10, suggesting an amplypositive strategy. However, thishasto be qualified on several grounds:
0 The average cereal productivity inthe selected countries is below 1tonha, varying from as low as 300 k g h a inpart o fNiger to over 1,000 k g h a inSenegal, for an estimated average o f 500 kgha. 0 Evenwithin an affected area, it is estimated that crop losses are not 100percent, but intherange of50percent.
7  0 Finally, given the extreme uncertainty o fthe area attacked, the area sprayed i s significantly greater than the area actually affected, ingeneral estimated to be twice as large.
35. Onthat basis, the costhenefit ratio o f control operations would be marginally positive at about 1to 2. This estimate is inlinewith a USAID analysis o f the efforts innine African countries in 1986which yieldeda return o f 1to 1,leading the assessment team to conclude that "the cost-effectiveness of the locust and grasshoppers controlprograms has not been demonstrated. . ."
36. This analysis needs to be qualified by several considerations that have conflicting effects on the justification for control campaigns. On the negative side, insecticide spraying has a cost interms o fhealth and environmental impact that i s difficult to quantifybutwhich isnot insignificant. Onthe positive side, estimates o fthe benefits based only on direct crop losses clearly underestimate the true cost o f the disasters. Some additional considerations include:
0 direct andindirect losses inthe livestock sector (mortality, reducedweight, conflicts due to early migration); 0 permanent loss o fproductive assets/capacity that will have negative effects on fbture production; 0 effects on general consumer prices for food andanimal feed; second-round effects o freduced agricultural incomes on the rural economy and the broader economy incountries which are heavily dependant o f agriculture; and 0 the long-term negative effects on general economic activity as a result o fthe reallocation o f scarce private andpublic resources to emergency control activities, and the loss o fhuman and social capital.
37. Onthe whole it would seem that a more inclusive costhenefit analysis considering most indirect andsecond-round effects would strengthen the economic justification o f control activities. The analysis also suggests that while large-scale control programs may have only limited economicjustification, more targeted control programs that focus on areas plantedto high-value crops andthat when sprayed accurately may have a much higher costhenefit ratio andjustification. EconomicJustificationof Early Warning andPreventionSystems 38. Economic studies o f desert locust control efforts are surprisingly scarce despite the considerable amount o f public hnds investedbythe concerned countries and the international community, and the seriousness o f locust outbreaks on economic growth andpoverty. The available data suggest that desert locusts do not ingeneral represent a serious threat. Crop losses caused by locusts at a national level, and across time, are generally small comparedto losses from other pests and natural disasters. Estimates o f the potential losses from anuncontrolled desert locust upsurge do not exceed 5-7 percent o fproduction inany given year (research inthe Sahelian rainfed sorghum andmilletbelt suggests that grasshoppers ingeneral cause more regular and chronic losses than do locusts). It also suggests that desert locusts are unlikelyto trigger widespread food insecurity, although they can and do cause localizedproblems when affected communities are already vulnerable. Most available technical studies are generally
8  skeptical about the benefit-cost ratios o f existing locust prevention strategies, while recognizing that the threat to commercial agriculture i s a more important factor. 39. One o f the available studies (Joffe, 1998) presents a preliminary analysis o fprevious upsurges and control and mitigation programs, and concludes that: The economic impact o f locust infestations depends on the extent o fthe infestation and the affected farming systems. Only severe and wide-spread infestations are likely to have an impact on overall national production and food security, although affected areas can suffer drastic and sometime total losses. Effective surveillance andcontrol mechanisms can prevent or drastically reduce most damage from locust outbreaks. Consideredindividually, because ofthe longremissionperiods between outbreaks, in most countries the economic justification o fmaintaining such a permanent surveillance and control mechanism appears doubtful. Such systems appearjustified only for countries which are at highrisk for major and frequent outbreaks (front-line countries) and/or countries that have intensive, high- value agriculture.
40. However, preliminary estimates (CIRAD, September 2004) appear to indicate that the failure to act immediately anddecisively to immediately suppress the upsurge was responsible for the dramatic increase inboththe cost of eradication and social and economic impact.

Benefitsof MitigationMeasuresfor AffectedPopulations 42. Justificationof ProposedAssistance to AffectedPopulations.Although the number of rural households already affected by the current upsurge has not yet been estimated, it is already apparent that this number i s highandwill probably increase inthe coming months with successive re-infestations that are likely to occur untilfinally eradicated. A simple multiplication o fthe area thought to havebeen infestedby the average rural population density, as providedby the World Development Indicators (2000), would indicate that more than 2 millionpeople may already have been directly affectedbythe locust invasion inseven countries (500,000 inSenegal, 350,000 in Mauritania, 500,000 inMali, and200,000 inNiger). Many are affectedto a degree beyond their traditional risk-copingmechanisms. Such damage, inaddition to the major economic shock it represents for already fragile economies heavily dependant on agriculture, would also be a major set-back for overall poverty reduction because it would predominantly affect the most vulnerable segments o fthe population. Although an accurate estimate o f the damage incurred by these populations i s not yet known, the justification o f associated mitigation measures is not questioned, rather the question i s generally one o fhow to implement such measures on a least-cost basis). 43. Needfor PublicAction for Risk Management.Along with violent conflicts, natural disasters are a major cause o f economic stagnation andvulnerability inAfrica, causing suddencollapse o fnational output andsharp increases inpoverty. Poor households are highlyvulnerable to negative shocks, whether they behealth, natural, policy-induced. Most have limited human, financial, physical, or social assets to cope with fluctuations in their income. Inparticular, heavyrelianceon agriculture exposes them to highlevels of natural risks from climate andplant and animal pests. Inaddition, natural disasters place all sources o f agricultural household income injeopardy because most income i s closely tied to farming. Thus, even households with a well-diversified incomeportfolio are still vulnerable to natural disasters. 44. Many rural households rely on informal mechanisms to cope with risk based on their financial andphysical capital (monetary and other savings, livestock) or social capital (family and communitynetworks). However, these mechanisms, ifthey work for idiosyncratic shocks, fail under a protracted crisis -such as the impact o f HIV/AIDS - or a severe event involvingcovariate risk such as most natural disasters. Finally, most o f these informal mechanisms are not available to the poorest households that have few assets and are based on reciprocity. Lack o f adequate risk mitigation mechanisms initiates a downward spiral inwhich actions to cope with the immediate crisis further reduce their ability to generate income and manage risk inthe long-term. They are thus forced to use
10  and sell whatever productive assets they own, which inturnreduces their income eaming capacity inthe future and locks them ina poverty trap. 45. It i s imperative for governments to quickly addressthe negative effects o fnatural disasters on agriculture for economic as well as social reasons. Inmost African countries agricultural growth has a strong multiplier effect on the rest o fthe economy (the non- farm economy grows at about the same rate as the farm economy). Therefore the impact of a reduction inagricultural production has an immediate impact on the entire national economy. Reducedproductive agricultural assets, ifnot addressed quickly, also reverberate for several years throughout the entire regional economy. Finally, highlevels o frisk also constrain agricultural households from engaging into a low-risWlow-retum investment strategy that prevents them from increasingproductivity andincome. Not only are agricultural households kept from accumulating the assets that would improve their risk management capacity, but their dilemma also has a severe negative impact on overall economic growth. 46. Naturalrisk management must thus be a critical part o f a government poverty reduction strategy. Cumulative experience clearly indicates that investinginprevention andpreparedness insteado freconstructionisjustified from an economic point o fview. Finally, the lack o f effective risk management instruments inrural households affects agricultural income and the overall economy andpoverty. Governments clearly play a critical role inproviding risk mitigation and safety net systems. Inthe long-term, market mechanisms manage some market-related risks and some natural disasters risks (insurance) andmay grow inimportance, although they are currently largely under- developed and unavailable ina large part o f the developing world. Public action is necessary not only to provide poor households with income opportunities -supporting their accumulation of human, financial, physical, and social assets and increasing their ability to cope with risk -but also to lessen their vulnerability to adverse shocks.
IV. ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT PesticideManagement 47. The hazards o fpoor pesticide management have beenknown for years, but few African countries have made significant efforts to address the problem. There i s now widespread support for concerted action as reflected inthe recommendations o f several African regional workshops -the Inter-government Forum on Chemical Safety (IFCS), the First Continental Conference for Africa onthe sound management o fhazardous waste held inRabat duringJanuary 2001,andthe adoption o f the Rabat Declaration bythe African Conference o f Ministers o f Environment inJuly 2002. However, because locust invasions are fast moving, regional, andrequire continuous surveillance, early warning, and rapid action at the national andregional levels, there is an urgentneed to develop a coherent regional framework o f action for more efficient locust control management. 48. There are two primaryinstitutional issues: capacity and strategies. 49. Lack of Adequate Technical, Institutional,andFinancialCapacity.Few Sahelian countries are currently equipped to prevent and react quickly to threatened locust invasions. Because o f the long remissionperiods between upsurges, many countries fail to maintain eventhe minimumcapacity necessaryto implement soundprevention
11  practices. Inparticular, many countries lack sufficient early warning anddecision-making systems, have inadequate storage andstock management, and a lack the training and education required for appropriate pesticide use. There i s also widespread misuse o f pesticides as a result o fpoor access to safety equipment, lack o fwarnings inlocal languages, and often low levels o f education among primary users. 50. InadequateProcurementStrategies.Inadequate procurement strategies by governments, national agencies, donor agencies, development organizations, and others are the principal cause o f risks from oversupply o fpesticides, supply o f unsuitable products, late delivery o fproducts, and supply ininappropriatepackage sizes. There is a need to improve pesticide management from the point o f supplyto the point o f use and beyond interms of, storage management, and disposal o f empty containers and unused pesticides. 51.The major environmentalrisksrelatedto locust control derive from: inadequate pesticide management practices duringlocust invasions; unsuitable products or packaging, including poor product specifications, unavailability of required application equipment, labels inforeign languages, lack o f trained personnel, etc.; donation or purchase inexcess o fneed that can result inproducts that have deteriorated during storage lack o f coordination among donor agencies so there may be duplicative, unsolicited, andor excessive donations; inadequate storage and strategic stock management, degradation o fpesticides that have a limitedshelf life andthat is further shortened by improper storage conditions (strategic stocks that are kept for emergencies become obsolete ifnot rotated properly); and commercial andor entrepreneurial interests override good management so there may be over-estimate o f needs, inappropriate product supply, or corruption).

LocustControlAlternatives 68. New InstitutionalArrangements. To improve future locust management, there i s a need to shift to an IPM-based strategy that considers the population dynamics o f the pest. The present strategy i s based on chemical control for bothprevention and control. An PM-based strategy would exploit natural mortality factors and consider new control alternatives. Alternative techniques being developed such as insect growth regulators, botanicals, semiochemicals, andbiopesticides would be considered. Although there already i s a substantial body o f research on the entomology andbiotopes o f locusts, their predators, and population dynamics, there i s a need to expand this knowledge and develop new andmore efficient control instruments. This i s a long-term endeavor that requires long-term financing and a critical mass o f scientists that does not exist inany single Sahelian country. There i s also a need to launch short-term adaptive research and transfer programs focusing on spray technologies. 69. Collaborative strategic and research anddevelopment (R&D) programs for locust management shouldbe undertakenthrough the national agricultural research systems (NARS) (including universities) inclose collaboration with the centers o fthe Consultative Group on InternationalAgricultural Research (CGIAR) and advanced
16  research institutions. It is recommended that centers o f excellence be identified among the participating NARSs as the focal point for this collaborative effort. Inaddition, given the specificity o f locust control strategies to prevent breeding and swarming andmassive control intervention, a strategic plano f action for locust management R&D, as well as a related set o f techniques for each stage andlevel o f intervention, should be developed, adapted, and transferred. Lines of Research for Locust Control Alternatives 69. A financial provisionhas been earmarked for each AELP country for this purpose. The mainlines o fresearchinclude alternative control instruments, biological solutions, population dynamics, and risk and damage assessment. 70. Alternative control instruments: Insect growth regulators (e.g., Diflubenzuron and Triflumuron) interfere with the production o f chitin and insect metamorphosis. IGRs are persistent, have low environmental impact, and are selective due to stomach action. Phenylpyrazoles (e.g., Fipronil) are persistent andthe formulation has low mammalian toxicity andi s a stomach andcontact poison. Chloronicotinyls (e.g., Imidacloprid) formulations already have low mammalian toxicity and are a stomach and contact poison. Botanical insecticides (e.g., neem) are available locally andcanbe prepared at the village level insmall quantities that have a low environmental impact. Semiochemicals (e.g., pheromones) maybe highly specific and safe products that can be usedto disperse bands and swarms. Experimental results on reduced feeding, marching, increasedpredation, cannibalism, and susceptibility to insecticides and pathogens are encouraging. None are available commercially. The International Center o f Insect Physiology andEcology (ICIPE) has identified an environment- friendly, specific and cost-effective agent, the locust pheromonephenylacetonitrile (PAN). Spraying larvae with the pheromonehas a lasting impact ontheir development andbehavior. Ifit i s mixed with other insecticides, the efficacy at these insecticides i s increased by a factor o ften to fifteen. Biopesticides (e.g., Metarhizium anisopliae var. acridum) are highly specific, have low mammaliantoxicity, and are safe for the environment. There are few production facilities on the African continent that could produce the formulation locally.
71. Biological Solution. Various research programs and inparticular the LUBILOSA project (Lutte BIologique contre les Locustes et Sauteriaux) investigatedbiological means o f controlling locusts and grasshoppers. A mycopesticide called GREEN MUSCLE@is based on the spores o f the insect pathogenic fungus M anisopliae var. acridum. This fungus, which appears to be specific to species o f short-horned grasshoppers, i s widely distributedinAfrica andunder favorable climatic conditions, can cause local epidemics ingrasshopper or locust populations. Its biological and physical properties make this fungus an ideal candidate for biological control. Spores o fM. anisopliae var. acridum can be easily mass-produced. 72. The efficacy o f GREENW S C L E O has been demonstrated inmany field trials carried out over the past ten years, including aerial application at an operational scale.
17  GREENMUSCLE@isbeingrecommended bythe pesticide referee group o fFAO. In South Africa the product was launched inMarch 1998, andhas beenregistered. GREEN MUSCLE@was registered for the Sahel in2001. Niger launched GREENMUSCLE@in August 2000 andis the first country which integrated GREENMUSCLE@into its grasshopper control operations. GREENMUSCLE@production i s also being developed inSenegal. 73. However, just launching the product will not necessarily leadto the required scale o f adoption. A modest transfer program i s therefore neededto ensure the large-scale uptake o fMetarhizium. This will involve activities to develop boththe supply and demandsides o fthe economic equation. Onthe supplyside, the objectives are to help production companies incase o fproblems andto advertise the availability o f Green Muscle. The demandside includes stimulating demandby information, publicity, and advocacy, and developing integrateduse strategies that capitalize on the particular properties o fMetarhizium. Inaddition, inorder to succeedthe program needs to have an enabling legal and fiscal environment that would help promote the use o fbio-pesticides. 74. PopulationDynamics.An IPM-based strategy is dependent on a clear understanding o fpest population dynamics andtheir interactionwith the ecosystem and management actions. The present early warning system relies on weather forecasting and satellite imaging o fvegetation cover. However, the present early warning systems does not integrate population dynamics data with weather and vegetation data to produce powerful simulation models that could beusedto monitor and apply decision tools. 75. Risk andDamageAssessment.Crop loss assessmentfor locust invasions is avery complex endeavor. Experts often disagree on the most appropriate and cost-effective protocols for systematic crop loss assessments. Cost-effective methodologies and protocols for a rapid assessment o f locust damage are desperately neededto get a clear understanding of the impacts o f locust invasions. 76. 32  BURKINA FASO EMERGENCYLOCUST PROJECT
I. ProjectBackground West Afr-ica i s facing its worst locust infestation in 15 years, spreading from the Atlantic coast to eastern Chad. The locust infestationwas first predicted by FA0 inOctober 2003. Significant infestationbegan in early 2004 inNorthwest Africa and has now spread to all Sahelian countries (Mauritania, Senegal, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, and Chad.
Infestation inBurkina were detected inAugust 2004 inthe provinces o f Oudalan, Soum, Seno, Yagha, Sanmatenga, andNamentenga inthe northern region o f the country. About 16,300 ha have been treated out o f the 109,000 ha that are infested. This compares to one-fifth o f the national territory, and includes about a 100 villages that have been seriously affected.
The cumulative effect of drought and the locust infestation has caused a significant loss o f ago-pastoral production. The consequences include a deficit in food security, increased cereal prices, unusual migration o f people, an early nomadic migration, and loss o f seeds for next year's agriculture production. Preliminary survey results carried out by the Directorate General o f Prediction and Agriculture Statistics indicate that one-third o f the deficit in agriculture production (estimated at 60 percent) inthe Sahelian zone of Burkina is due to the locust infestation. In addition, there has been a significant degradation of pastures in this zone, which is the most important livestock production area inthe country.
11. Government Response, Strategy and Program Government Strategy - Since the neighboring countries announced the presence o f locusts in their countries, the Government initiated an emergency program to prevent the infestation o f Burkina Faso. That program included: (i) strengthening crop protection agencies by improving communication networks, rehabilitation o f vehicles, acquisition o f new prospecting and treatment vehicles, and 2,000 personnelprotection kits; (ii) increase o f 2,800 liters stocks o f pesticides with 31,000 liters; (iii) training and organization o f producers into treatment brigades; (iv) raising the awareness o f the local population so that they could signal infestations; and (v) the setting up a monitoring and evaluation system.
Interms oforganization, the Government has set up the following entities at the national level: (i)a National Locust Control Committee that includes the primary partners and financiers o f the locust control effort. The committee meets weekly and i s responsible for
33  mobilizing the resources (human and financial) required for locust control, and (ii)a Technical Committee that includes members o f the ministries in charge o f agriculture, environment, livestock, research, and some consultants and experts. The Technical Committee i s incharge o f monitoring the evolution o f the locust infestation, and informs the National Locust Control Committee. Ithas undertaken four field supervision missions per month, andprepared reports for the national committee andthe cabinet.
At the provincial level, a Provincial Coordination Committee directed by the High Commissioner includes relevant structure and all Directorates in charge o f agriculture, animal resources, environment, health, representatives o f the NGOs, and producers. This committee is incharge o f supervisingsurveillance and ground level locust control. At the departmental level, Crop Protection Units include Prefects and departmental officers o f the ministries and o f producers. These units are in charge o f identifying and marking infested areas, mobilizing producers to help with the treatments, and informing the provincial committee on the evolution o f the infestations. Finally, at the village level, producers are organized into Brigades o f 50-100 people who collectively undertake treatments.
At the regional and sub-regional level, FA0 and CILSS have provided regular information on the locust invasion, but there were no operational coordination actions. Bilateral collaborationhas been initiatedwith Mali for treatment inthe border zones.
The emergency program has been implementedwith 28 prospecting andtreatment teams, o f which three are deployed inMali. Each team consists o f 10 people, including a team- leader, two prospectors, two drivers, and five handymen. The Government has mobilized 5 four-wheel drive vehicles and one helicopter for the prospecting and treatment operations. In addition, it has procured one US$ 14 million airplane. A total o f 8,300 producers have beentrained and organized into about 100 treatment brigades, but despite this effort many areas have been infested. The main reasons for this are: (i) used old vehicles have prevented the treatment o f large surfaces, (ii) insufficient number o f an pulverizers, (iii)the lack o f means to provide training, (iv) limited communication equipment, (v) lack o f spare parts, (vi) weak capacity for airborne interventions, (vii) insufficient resources for operational cost, and (viii) insufficient coordination at the regional level.
Inthe short-term, the government will provide food for affected populations through a delivery mechanism that includes local NGOs. In addition, the government seeks to increase agricultural productivity and support income-generating activities that would benefit the most affected populations.
Inthe long-term, the government envisages rehabilitating the monitoring network by creation o f a locust control base inDori. This new base will cover northem Burkina areas andborder areas toward Niger andMali.
Technical partners and donors have supported government efforts in locust control. A total o fUS$1.7million has beenreceived from 13 national and internationaldonors.
34  111. Bank Strategy Bankassistance will support the Government's overallprogram. Itwillbeprovidedunder the Bank's Emergency Procedures (OP/BP 8.50). It will provide support to the Government's emergency locust controVeradication operations, complementing the assistanceprovided by other donors, but its main focus will be on: (i) rehabilitation o f the destroyed assets and productive capacities o f affected populations and the provision o f alternative sources o f employment and revenue through cash-for-work, publicly-funded micro-projects, and infrastructure programs; and (ii)strengthening capacity for surveillance, early warning systems, and response mechanisms at national and regional levels to reduce the risk and potential social, economic, and environmental impact o f future infestations.
IV. Project Description Overall Objectives -The overall objective o f the project is to prevent or the minimize economic and social impact from damage due to the current locust infestation, and to improve the national capacity to predict and control future infestations and mitigate their impact on the national economy and population. The project i s fully in line with NEPAD's Comprehensive African Agriculture Program (CAADP), which emphasizes better disaster preventiodmitigation andrisk management as one on the main instruments for growth and poverty alleviation.
The project will be an integral part o f a national program funded by all donors in a coordinated fashion. It includes: (i) an emergency phase (2004-2005, funded by resources already mobilized and IDA'Sresources including those o f the PPF); and (ii) a medium-term program aimed a strengthening national and regional capacities for surveillance, early warning, response, mitigation, risk management, and pesticide use and management. The progradproject includes four components:
Emergency Locust Management (controVeradication andpesticide management); EmergencyAssistance to affected populations; Strengthening o f early warning andresponse capacities; . Project management.
The project, like government's overall program, will focus on areas particularly at risk in six o fBurkina Faso's provinces. It has been designed on an emergency basis, on the basis o f available, sometime incomplete information. It i s therefore likely that it will need to be adjusted to fit the actual evolution o f the situation on the ground. This will require an efficient monitoring and evaluation system from the start o f the program.
Project Components The project will have the following four components:
1. Component A - Emergency Locust Management - This component will support government activities increasing the national capacity for:
35  Tracking locust infestations, including inneighboringcountries;
Increasing quick response capacity for effective control operations if an infestation does happen, as appears likely, in the coming months; awareness/information campaigns; training o f farming communities; transport and other equipment for locust detection and control brigades; emergency stocks o f pesticides; protection gear; telecommunication equipment; and related operating costs;
Carryingout immediate actual field controVeradication operations inearly 2005 andpossibly in2006;
Improving the management o f pesticides through a detailed inventory o f locust control pesticides (to ensure that no bannedchemicals are imported or used); the safe transport, packaging, storage, and destruction o f locust control pesticides in accordance with international standards (International Code o f Conduct).
2. Component B - Emergency Assistance to Affected Populations - This component will provide assistance to affected populations to restore their productive capacity and provide temporary employmenthncome earningopportunities:
(i) Restoration of productive capacity. This will be done through several approaches, based on careful targeting, depending on the specific characteristics o f the concerned areas and populations through in kind assistance -distribution o f "starter packs" o f inputs (seeds, fertilizers, tools, animal feed, etc.) - where necessary; distribution of a cash allowance corresponding to the estimated cost o f the inputs necessary for resuming production (allowing beneficiaries to decide what to purchase and where); and, when appropriate, the partial cancellatiodrescheduling o floans); and
(ii) Provision o f alternative employment opportunities. This will provide affected populations with temporary income opportunities while normal income streams are restored through locally planned and managed cash-for-work programs targeted at collective infrastructure (feeder roads, dams/ irrigatioddrainage, bottomland development).
3. Component C - Strengthening Early Warning and Response Capacities - This component will support the strengthening o f national and regional capacities for locust infestation surveillance, control and mitigation; and the preparation o f national and regional strategies to manage natural disastershisks inrural areas. Specifically, it will support:
(i) Sensitization and training of farming communities/groups to locust and other pest detection and control;
36  (ii) Strengtheningthenationalpestmanagementservices (additionalhuman resources, constructionhehabilitation o f facilities, specialized equipment) to ensure minimum efficiency and viability during remission periods and an adequate quick response capability incase o f emergency;
(iii) Implementationofastrengthenedresearchprogramonlocustbiological control and IPM, carried out through the national agricultural research system (IER) but also throughparticipation (researchers, financial) injoint regionalresearch programs carried out under CORAF coordination;
(iv) Participation in collective activities at the regional level such as an operational/institutional audit o f the current regional system for locust and other pest management systems aimed at improving their efficiency and sustainability; and the design o f a regional mechanism for natural disaster risk management in rural areas (based on close integration between local, national, and regional instruments).

Component D - Project Management - This component will support the cost o f project management unit (office rehabilitation and equipment, short-term consultancies, incremental operating costs), including financial and technical audits, and participation in coordination meetings at the regional level. It will in particular finance the design, establishment, and operations o f a comprehensive M&E program (including economic, social and environmental impacts as well as cross boundaries issues) based on and fully integratedwith existing institutional and M&E systems.

Project Implementation - The Ministry in charge o f Agriculture will be responsible for project implementation. The project i s multi-sectoral and will be implemented under the guidance of a steering committee, including representatives from government, donors and the civil society. A Project Coordinator will be appointed within the Department o f Crop Production to manage and coordinate Project implementation activities. The Project Coordinator will be responsible for (i) preparing detailed implementation plans and budgets, (ii)discussing these plans and budgets with participating donors; (iii) supervisingimplementation activities; (iv) coordinatingwith regional institutions; and(v) reporting on the use o f resources and results. The PC will be responsible for coordinating the support o f all external donors, ensuring coherence and transparence in the use o f all available resources, and for timely and accurate reporting. The responsibilities and accountability o f the Project Coordinator will be detailed in a performance contract agreed upon with the Inter-Ministerial Locust Control Committee. The financial management and procurement activities will be managed by a community-based rural development project (PNGTII). that i s already established and operating according to procedures satisfactory to IDA.
It will be implemented through existing institutions and used to strengthen the national institutional framework. Local communities/populations will be closely associated with the planning, implementation, and monitoring o f its activities. For implementation o f its activities, the project will collaborate with various national partners (Department of Agricultural Services, National Agricultural Research Institute, National Environment Agency, Department of Finances, Department o f Health Services, Non-Governmental Organizations, and the Department of Animals Resources), as well as with institutions in other countries and relevant regional institutions for collective action relating to regional public goods. This is in particular the case for the proposed research program which focuses on adaptive research, mainly researchrelatedthe use o fbio-pesticides.
Particular attention will be given to the detailed mechanism for targeting project assistance to affected populations and monitoring o f efficient delivery. The detailed Project/program Implementation Plan (PIP), including the detailed targeting system, and Monitoring and Evaluation System (M&E) will be agreed upon and established at the start o fproject.
As already mentioned, the project is part o f government's overall locust emergency management program, and has been designed on the basis o f available information and best estimates about the future evolution o f the infestation and its impact on agricultural communities. 50  CHAD EMERGENCY LOCUST PROJECT
I. ProjectBackground West Africa is facing its worst locust infestation in 15 years, spreading from the Atlantic coast to eastern Chad. The locust infestation was first predictedby FA0 inOctober 2003. Significant infestation began inearly 2004 inNorthwest Africa and has now spread to all Sahelian countries (Mauritania, Senegal, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, and Chad).
Chad i s one o f the four countries hosting DL breeding areas in West Africa. The first signs o f infestation in Chad were detected in July 2004 in the Sahelian regions. Two thirds o f the country were affected by the DL infestation. The Government, with the support o f FA0 and donors represented inthe Country, started control operation in July 2004. About 16,500 ha were treated at the end o f October 2004. The main issues faced by Government included lack o f resources, vehicles, sprayers, aerial control teams, and ground control teams.
During Se tember hopper groups and bands o f all instars, at densities up to 130 hoppershnf were mixed with scattered adults in the central region o f Batha, in the northeastern regions o f Arada, and inthe eastern region o f Ouadai.
However, swarms are reproducing and migrating across borders following a so-called "circular migration" between North Africa and the Sahelian zone, which may cause multiplesuccessive seasonal attacks over two to three years as has happened inprevious infestations. Chad i s mostly likely to be affected by Desert Locust (DL) swarms that will start moving back southward inthe winter and early spring o f 2005, and at least 800,000 hamay have to be treated again in2005 and possibly halfthat area in2006.
It is too early to have precise estimates o f crop andpasture losses suffered so far in2004. However, it i s already estimated that up to 100,000 tons o f cereals may have been lost already due to the locust invasion (out o f a total shortfall o fabout 300,000 tons which i s also linked to the significant rain deficit experienced in producing areas). There i s mounting evidence o f large scale distress sales o f livestock because o f the lack o f pasture and fodder. Inaddition, the lackofadequatefodder for livestockhasinducedthe premature migrationof herds to the south, sometime through unusual routes, which will increase the occurrence of conflicts with local farmers. Although the impact o fthe invasionon national food security i s still being estimated, there is no doubt that its impact at the household level has been devastating. Because of the specific characteristics o f locust damage (juxtaposition o f areas where losses are nearly complete with areas which are totally spared). Families intheworst affected areas have lost up to 100% o ftheir production and are thus destitute. It i s estimated that upto 200.000 households (1,500,000 persons) will need food aid as well as assistanceto
51  restore their productive assets and access to transitory employment and income opportunities.
Finally, as demonstrated by previous infestations (1988 and 1994), the negative impact of locust infestations i s not only short-term. They reverberates for a number o f years on the national economy because o f the forced diversion o f scarce development resources to fight the plague andthe wide-spread destruction o fproductive assets. There i s thus an immediate need to (i) take all necessary measures to suppress and eradicate locust swarms as they return inearly 2005 to prevent further damage andrural families beingpushed into absolute poverty; and(ii) assist affected populations to restore their productive capacity. There is also a need to build national and regional capacities for locust surveillance, early warning, control, and mitigation, as well more generally as for developing more effective strategies andmechanisms to managerisks inruralareas.
11. GovernmentResponse, Strategy andProgram Government Strategy. In the spring o f 2004, on the basis o f the lessons learned and following consultations with FAO, the government o f Chad has taken early action to efficiently mobilize domestic and external resources for controlling and suppressing the infestation. It (i)established an Inter-Ministerial Locust Control Committee, chaired by the Minister o f Agriculture, to coordinate government action andmobilize resources; (ii) designed an action plan for Locust control; (iii)conducted assessment surveys to determine presence o f DL; (iv) carried out sensitization campaigns for farmers and other stakeholders (press conferences,); (v) established twelve ground detectiodcontrol teams; (vi) mobilized farmer ground control brigades; and (vii) organized DLcontrol training to strengthen staff involved in control activities. Finally, the government has organized weekly meetings with domestic and external partners - FAO, UNDP, EU, WFP, ambassadors, international development institutions, NGOs, the public and private sectors -to mobilize and efficiently coordinate the needed assistance. The government designed an action plan for locust control, the restoration o f agricultural assets and productivity in areas affected by locust invasion. This program<waspresented at the Locust Control Meeting, held inJuly 2004 at Dakar, Senegal.
111. BankStrategy Bank assistance will support the Government's overall program. It will be provided under the Bank's Emergency Procedures (OPBP 8.50). It will provide support to Government's emergency Locust control/eradication operations, complementing the assistance provided by other donors but its main focus will be on (i) rehabilitation o f destroyed assets and the productive capacities o f affected populations and the provision o f alternative sources o f employment and revenue through cash-for-work publicly h d e d micro-projects and infi-astructure programs; and (ii) strengthening capacity for surveillance, early warning systems, and response mechanisms at the national and regional levels to reduce the risk andpotential social, economic, andenvironmental impact o ffuture infestations.
52  IV. Project Description Overall Objectives. The overall objective o f the project is to minimize economic and social damage due to the current locust infestation, and to improve the national capacity to predict and control future infestations and mitigate their impact on the national economy and populations. The project is fully in line with the Chad poverty reduction strategy and rural developmental strategy. It i s also fully in line with NEPAD's Comprehensive Afkican Agriculture Program (CAADP) which emphasizes better disaster preventiodmitigation and risk management as one on the main instruments for growth andpoverty alleviation.
The project will be an integral part o f a national program funded by all donors in a coordinated fashion. It includes: (i) an emergency phase (2004-2005, funded by resources already mobilized and IDA'Sresources including those o f the PPF); and (ii) a medium- term program aimed at strengthening national and regional capacities for surveillance, early warning, response, mitigation, risk management, and pesticide use and management. The progradproject includes four components:
0 Locust control and eradication, andpesticide management;
0 Assistance to affectedpopulations; Strengthening of capacities o f forecasting, early warning, response andmitigation (including regional cooperation); Programmanagement.
The project, like the government's overall program, will focus on areas particularly at risks in the Lac, Kanem, Batha, Ouaddai, Wadi Fira, and Bet regions that represent two- third o f the country. It has been designed on an emergency basis, on the basis o f available, sometime incomplete information. It i s therefore likely that it will need to be adjusted to fit the actual evolution o f the situation on the ground. This will require the establishment from the start o f the program o f an efficient M&E system.
Project Components The project will have the following four components:
1. Component A - Emergency Locust Control - This component will support government activities increasing the national capacity for:
(i) Tracking locust infestation focusing on breeding areas, including in neighboring countries;
(ii) Increasing quick response capacity for effective control operations if an infestation does happen, as is likely in the coming months: awarenesshnformation campaigns, training o f farming communities, transport and other equipment for locust detection and control brigades, emergency stocks o f pesticides, protection gear; telecommunication equipment, andrelated operating costs;
53  (iii) Carrying out immediate actual field controVeradication operations should an outbreak materialize inearly 2005 ;
(iv) Improving the management o f pesticides through a detailed inventory o f Locust control pesticides (to ensure that no banned chemicals re imported or used); the safe transport, packaging, storage and destruction o f Locust control pesticides, in accordance with international standards (International Code of Conduct).
2. Component B - Restoration o f Populations Productive Capacities - This component will provide assistanceto potentially affected populations through:
(i) The distribution o f "starter packs" o f inputs (seeds, fertilizers, tools, animal feed, etc.) to maintainhestore the productive capacities o f the affected farmers and herders; and
(ii) The undertaking o f cash-for-work programs or collective productive micro-projects (dams, irrigatioddrainage, bottomland development), to provide alternative sources o f employment and revenues until the normal income streams are restored.
3. Component C - Strengthening National Capacities - This component will support the strengthening o f national capacities, and o f the regional capacities for undertaking collective action for surveillance/early warning, and control and mitigation o f locust (and other pests) infestations. Specifically, it will support:
The sensitization and training o f farming communities/groups to locust/pest detection and control;
The complementary equipment o f the national pest management services (constructionhehabilitation o f facilities, specialized equipment) and the training, o f its staff;
The implementation o f a strengthened research program on Locust biological control and IPM, inparticular through participation into a joint regional research program under C O W ;
Short-term technical assistance and studies to develop a comprehensive national natural risk management/vulnerabilityreduction strategy to be integrated into The Gambia's overall PRSP and rural development strategy; and strengthen the close integration o f national programs/activities into the regional framework for locust and other pest management systems.
4. Component D - Project Management and Coordination - This component will support the cost o f project management unit (office rehabilitation and equipment, short-term consultancies, incremental operating costs), including financial and technical audits,
54  and participation in coordination meetings at the regional level. It will in particular finance the design, establishment, and operations o f a comprehensive M&E system (including economic, social and environmental impacts as well as cross-boundaries issues) based on and fully integrated with existing institutional and M&E systems.

Project Implementation - The Ministry of Agriculture will be responsible for project implementation. The project is o f a multi-sectoral nature and it will be implemented under the guidance of the Inter-MinisterialLocust Control Committee which be enlarged to include representatives from farmers Organization and NGOs. A Project Coordinator will be appointed within the Secretariat of Agriculture to manage and coordinate the activities of the Project. The Project Coordinator will be responsible for (i) preparing
56  detailed implementation plans and budgets, (ii) discussing these plans and budgets with the steering committee including participating donors; (iii) supervising implementation activities; (iv) coordinating with regional institutions; and (v) and reporting on the use o f resources and results achieved. The financial management and procurement activities will be implemented through the Agricultural Services and Producers Organization Project (ASPOP) which i s already established and operating according to procedures satisfactory to IDA. The PC will be responsible for coordinating the support o f all external donors, ensuring coherence and transparence inthe use o f all available resources, and for timely and accurate reporting.
The Project will be implemented through existing institutions and used for strengthening the national institutional framework. Local communities/populations will be closely associated to the planning, implementation and monitoring o f its activities. For the implementation of its activities, the project will collaborate with various national partners (Ministry o f Livestock, National Agricultural Research Institute, Ministry o f Environment, Ministry o f Planning, Ministry o f Health Services, Non Governmental Organizations, Farmers and Herders Organizations) as well as with institutions in other countries and relevant regional institutions for collective actions concerning regional public goods. This i s inparticular the case for the proposedresearch program which will be implemented with the national research institute and within a regional CORAF network and insynergy with a COR4.F member international institute.
Particular attention will be given to the detailed mechanism for targeting project assistance to affectedpopulations and to the monitoring o f efficient delivery.The detailed Project/program Implementation Plan (PIP), including the detailed targeting system, and Monitoring and Evaluation System (M&E) will be agreed upon and established at project start up.

I. ProjectBackground West Africa is facing its worst locust infestation in 15 years, spreading from the Atlantic coast to eastern Chad. The locust infestation was first predicted by FA0 inOctober 2003. Significant infestationbegan inearly 2004 inNorthwest Africa andhas now spread to all Sahelian countries (Mauritania, Senegal, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, and Chad).
The first signs o f infestation inMali were detected inlate 2003 inthe Northern region o f the country. About 40,000 ha were immediately treated and the outbreak was thought to be under control. However, favorable conditions in the Southern Atlas region permitted large new swarms to form and reinvade Mali and the other front-line states (Mauritania, Niger, Chad) inthe spring o f 2004. More than 70 swarms o f up to 2.0 million insects /ha were detected along the front-line zone from Mali to Mauritania. It i s estimated that between May and October 2004, locusts covered more than 750,000 ha where they have caused wide-spread crop andpasture losses.
The Government o f Mali resumed control operations in March 2004. About 350,000 ha have been treated and the upsurge has been brought under control again, at least temporarily. Numerous swarms have moved north into northwest Mauritania, Western Sahara, and the foothills o f the Atlas mountains in Algeria where intensive aerial and ground control operations were immediately initiated.
However, swarms are reproducing and migrating across borders following a so-called "circular migration" between North Africa and the Sahelian zone, which may cause multiplesuccessive seasonal attacks over two to three years as has happened inprevious infestations. Mali i s mostly likely to be affected by Desert Locust (DL) swarms that will start moving southward again in the winter and early spring o f 2005 and that at least 650,000 ha may have to be treated again in2005 andpossibly halfthat area in2006.
It is too early to have precise estimates o f crop and pasture losses suffered so far in2004. However, it i s already estimated that up to 150,000 tons o f cereals may have been lost already due to the locust invasion (out o f a total shortfall o f about 400,000 tons which is linked to a significant rain deficit inproducing areas). There i s mounting evidence o f large- scale distress sales o f livestock because o f the lack o f pasture and fodder. In addition, the lack o f adequate fodder for livestock has induced the premature migration o f herds to the south, sometime through unusual routes, which will increase the occurrence o f conflicts with local farmers. Although the impact of the invasion on national food security is still beingestimated, there isno doubt that its impact at the household levelhasbeendevastating.
72  Because o f the specific characteristics o f locust damage (juxtaposition o f areas where losses are near complete with areas which are totally spared). Families in the worst affected areas have lost up to 100 percent o ftheir production. They are thus destitute andneed emergency assistance. It i s estimated that up to 100,000 farm families (1,000,000 persons) will need food aid as well as assistanceto restore their productive assets andhave access to transitory employment and income opportunities.
Finally, as demonstrated by previous infestations (1988 and 1994), the negative impact o f locust infestationis not only short-term. Itreverberates for a number o f years on the national economy because o f the forced diversion o f scarce development resources to fight the plague andthe wide-spread destruction o fproductive assets. There i s thus a immediate need to (i) all necessarymeasures to suppress and eradicate locust swarms as they return in take early 2005 to prevent additional damage and rural families being pushed fiuther into absolute poverty; and (ii) assist affected populations to restore their productive capacity. There is also a need for building national and regional capacities for locust surveillance, early warning, control and mitigation, as well more generally to for develop more effective strategies andmechanisms to manage risks inrural areas.
11. Government Response, Strategy, and Program Government Strategy - In the spring o f 2004, on the basis o f the lessons learned and following consultations with the Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO), the government o f Mali has taken early action for efficiently mobilizing domestic and external resources for controlling and suppressing the infestation. It (i)established an Inter-Ministerial Locust Control Committee, chaired by the Minister o f Agriculture, to coordinate government action and mobilize resources; (ii) conducted assessment surveys to determine presence o f DL; (iii) carried out sensitizations campaigns for fanners and other stakeholders (press conferences, informatiodinstruction bulletins to the farming communities and the general public for the sighting and reporting o f DL); (iv) established 35 ground detectiodcontrol teams and mobilized 12 planes and 1 helicopter for aerial spraying' (v) mobilized more than 15,000 farmers and volunteers for ground brigades; (vi) mobilized the national army for logistics and ground operations; and (vii) acquired (480,000 liters) and distributed (270,000 liters) pesticides, spraying equipment (18 truck- mounted and 2,500 man-carried), communication equipment and protective gears for the locust control teams. An operational command post has been created in August 2004, headed by the Police Chief Officer, to coordinate field operations. Finally, the government has organized weekly meetings with domestic and external partners -- FAO, UNDP, EU, Ambassadors, international development institutions, NGOs, the public and private sectors - to mobilize and efficiently coordinate the needed assistance. The government also designed a detailed operational program for Locust control and the restoration o f agricultural assets and productivity in areas affected by locust invasion. This program was presented at the Locust control Meeting, held in July 2004 Dakar, Senegal. As a result, control activities have intensified over the summer and it is estimated that more than 350,000 hectares o f infested land have so far been treated. The infestation has been temporarily brought under control.
73  111. Bank Strategy Bank assistance will support Government's overallprogram. Itwillbeprovidedunderthe Bank's Emergency Procedures (OPBP 8.50). It will provide support to Government's emergency Locust control/eradication operations, complementing the assistance provided byother donors but its main focus will be on (i) rehabilitation o fdestroyed assets and the productive capacities of affected populations [and the provision of alternative sources o f employment and revenues through cash-for-work publicly funded micro-projects and infrastructure programs]; and (ii) strengthening o f capacities for surveillance, early the warning systems and response mechanisms at national but also at regional levels, for reducing the risk and potential social, economic and environmental impact of future infestations.
IV. Project Description
Overall Objectives - The overall objective o f the project is to prevent or the minimize economic and social impact damage due to the current locust infestation, and to improve the national capacity to predict and control future infestations and mitigate its impact on the national economy and populations. The project is fully inline with The Mali poverty reduction strategy and rural developmental strategy. It i s also fully inline with NEPAD's Comprehensive African Agriculture Program (CAADP) which emphasizes better disaster preventiodmitigation and risk management as one on the main instruments for growth and poverty alleviation.
The project will be an integral part o f a national program funded by all donors in a coordinated fashion. It includes: (i) an emergency phase (2004-2005, funded by resources already mobilized andIDA'Sresources including those o f the PPF); and (ii) a medium-tenn program aimed a strengthening national and regional capacities for surveillance, early warning, response, mitigation, risk management and pesticide use and management. The progradproject includes four components:
Emergency Locust Management (controVeradication andpesticide management); Emergency Assistance to affected populations; Strengthening of early warning and response capacities; Project management.
The project, like government's overall program, will focus on areas particularly at risks in seven of Mali 9 regions (in total about 130 communes out of the country 702, see annexl). It has beendesigned on an emergency basis, on the basis o f available, sometime incomplete information. It i s therefore likely that it will need to be adjusted to fit the actual evolution o f the situation on the ground. This will require the establishment from the start o fthe program o f an efficient monitoring andevaluation system.
Project Components The project will have four components:
74  1. Component A - Emergency Locust Management - This component will support government activities increasingthe national capacity for:
(i) Tracking locust infestation, including inneighboringcountries;
(ii) Increasing quick response capacity for effective control operations ifan infestation does happen, as it is likely, inthe coming months: awareness/information campaigns, training o f farming communities, transport andother equipment for locust detection andcontrol brigades, emergency stocks o fpesticides, protection gear; telecommunication equipment, and related operating costs;
(iii) Carrying out immediate actual field control/eradication operations inearly 2005, and possibly in2006;
(iv) Improving the management o fpesticides through: a detailed inventory o f locust control pesticides (to ensure that no bannedchemicals re imported or used); the safe transport, packaging, storage and destructiono flocust control pesticides, inaccordance with international standards (International Code o f Conduct).
2. Component B - Emergency Assistance to Affected Populations - This component will provide assistance to affected populations for the restoration o f their productive capacity and the provision o ftemporary employment/income earning opportunities:
(9 Restoration of productive capacity. This will be done through several approaches, based on careful targeting, depending on the specific characteristics o f the concerned areas and populations: through in kind assistance --distribution o f << starter packs ))o f inputs (seeds, fertilizers, tools, animal feed, etc.)-where necessary; through distribution o f a cash allowance corresponding to the estimated cost o f the inputs necessary for resuming production (allowing beneficiaries to decide what to purchase and where); and, when appropriate, through the partial cancellatiodrescheduling o f loans) ;and
(ii) Provision of alternative employmentopportunities. Thiswillbedone to provide affected populations with temporary income opportunities while normal income streams are restored through locally planned and managed cash for work programs targeted at collective infrastructure (feeder roads, dams/irrigation/drainage,bottomlanddevelopment).

Component C: Strengthening o f early Warning and Response Capacities - This component will support the strengthening o f national and regional capacities for locust infestation surveillance, control and mitigation; and the preparation o f national and regional strategies for the management o f natural disasterdrisks in rural areas. Specifically, it will support:

The strengthening o f the national Locust management services (additional human resources, constructionhehabilitation o f facilities, specialized equipment) to ensure minimum efficiency and viability during remission periods and an adequate quick response capability incase o f emergency;
The implementation o f a strengthenedresearch program on locust biological control and IPM, carried out through the national agricultural research system (SNRA) but also through participation (researchers, financial) in joint regional researchprograms carried out under C O W coordination;

The participation in collective activities at regional level such as an operationalhnstitutional audit o f the current regional system for locust and other pest management systems aimed at improving their efficiency and sustainability; and the design o f a regional mechanism for natural disaster risk management in rural areas (based on close integration between local, national andregional instruments).
