Use of statements of expenditure - The following expenses can be submitted on a SOE basis: (a) contracts with an estimated value o f less than US$500,000 for works; (b) contracts with an estimated value o f less than US$250,000 for equipment and goods; (c) contracts with an estimated value o f less thanUS$lOO,OOO for consulting firms and less than US$50,000 for individual consultants; and (e) training, Micro-Grants and incremental operating expenses which may be claimed on the basis o f SOEs. Documentationsupporting all expenditures claimed against SOEs will be retainedby PMU, andwill be available for review when requested by IDA supervision missions and auditors. All disbursements are subject to the conditions o f the Development Credit Agreement andthe procedures defined inthe Disbursement Letter.
All application for the withdrawal o f proceeds from the credit will be fully documented for expenditures for Pesticide, regardless o fthe amount.
When project implementationbegins, the quarterly Financial MonitoringReports (FMRs) produced by the project will be reviewed. Strengthening its accounting and financial management capacity will enable PMU to establish effective financial management and accounting systems, which should facilitate to produce the Financial Monitoring Report (FMR). Where the reports are adequate and produced on a timely basis, and a borrower requests conversion to report-based disbursements, a review will be undertaken by the Task Team Leader (TTL), to determine if the project is eligible. The adoption o f report- based disbursements by the project will enable it to move away from time consuming voucher by voucher.
Disbursement Conditions - No withdrawals shall be made in respect of: (a) payments made for expenditures prior to the date o f this Agreement; (b) payments made under category (3),(i) unless the Borrower has fumished to the Association a Pest Management Plan in form and substance satisfactory to the Association, and (ii) for the purchase o f pesticides not included in the Authorized Pesticides List; and (c) payments made under category (6), unless Micro-Grants have been made in accordance with the provisions set

Project account - This account will be opened in a commercial bank acceptable to IDA. Counterpart funds will be deposited regularlyin this account in accordance with project needs. To facilitate disbursements for eligible expenditures for goods, works and services, uponproject effectiveness, the government would be required to make a deposit into the project account o f CFAF30,000,000 covering an estimated six months o f eligible expenditures co-financed bythe government.
Procurement Arrangements The project will beunder the responsibility o fthe Ministryo fAgriculture.
Fiduciary responsibility will be under the PIUo fthe Agricultural Services andProducer's organizations Project ("Projet d'Appui aux Services Agricoles et aux Organisations de Producteurs -PASAOP")
Summary of Assessment of theAgency's Capacity to Implement Procurement Procurement activities will be carried out bythe PIUo f the PASAOP. The agency is staffed by 6 high level staff and the Procurement unit is staffed by one procurement officer. A Project Implementation Manual i s in place and refers, in addition to the procurement procedures, to the SBDs to be used. In Mali, the central procurement control entity has published SBDs under an IDF grant allocated by the Bank; those SBDs are also used when applicable.
An assessment o f the capacity o f the Implementing Agency to implement procurement actions for the project has been carried out by Cheick A. T. Traore, Procurement Specialist inthe Country Office o f Mali, on November 4,2004. The assessment reviewed the organizational structure for implementing the project and the interaction between the project's staff responsible for procurement Officer and the Ministry's relevant central unit for administration andfinance. The ProcurementOfficer has support from the central unitfor administration and finance, andworks closelywith it.
Most o f the issues/ risks concerning the procurement component for implementation o f the project have beenidentified and include: a slight insufficiency in the preparation o f procurement plans, some sections o f the bidding documents, inparticular the evaluation criteria in the data sheet (for goods and for consultants selection), and the technical specifications in the case o f goods. Actually the workload is sustainable in the procurement unit, but inthe case o f a new project, it may happen some rushes from time to time, andthen a need o fpunctual support may occur.
The corrective measures which have been agreed are: training clinics (on the site) on the issues that have been identified, anticipating on rushperiods andprovide the procurement unitwithnecessary support staffinorder to avoid eventualdelays.
The overall project risk for procurement is from highto medium.

I ProjectBackground West Africa is facing its worst locust infestation in 15 years, spreading from the Atlantic coast to eastern Chad. The locust infestationwas first predictedby FA0 inOctober 2003. Significant infestation began inearly 2004 inNorthwest Africa and has now spread to all Sahelian countries (Mauritania, Senegal, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, and Chad.
Mauritania is a permanentrecession area for locusts that live inthe dry Northern regions o f the country. It is also a zone o f gregarious locust activity and the country has been regularly affected by serious, sometimes devastating outbreaks. Four such outbreaks occurred over the last 40 years (1968, 1974, 1987-88, and 1993-94). The first signs o f the current infestation were detected in September 2003, with important swarms arriving from the East, and immediate action was taken by the government. In total, 335,000 ha were treated over an 11 months period, and by M a y 2004, the infestation was totally suppressed. However, a second massive upsurge o f swarms (more than 200 large swarms have been reported) coming from North Africa started inlate July 2004 and an estimated 1.6 million ha have again been infested, with massive damages to crops and pastures. About 550,000 ha have been treated both through aerial spraying and ground treatments. This has offered control, but not eradication o f the infestation. Numerous swarms have now moved north into Northwest Sahara, the foothills o f the Atlas mountains inMorocco and Algeria where intensive aerial and ground control operations were immediately initiated. Other swarms have moved to the Cape Verde islands. However, swarms are reproducing and migrating across borders following a so-called "circular migration" between North Africa and the Sahelian zone, which causes multiple successive attacks over two to three years as has happened in previous infestations. Mauritania will very likely be affected by locust swarms moving back Southward over the winter and early spring o f 2005, and it is expected that large areas will be affected again and will need to betreated again in2005 andpossibly in2006.
It is too early to have precise information on crop and pasture losses so far in 2004. WFP/CILSS evaluation teams are completing field assessmentsthat will be available by the end o fNovember 2004. However, it is already estimated that all main agricultural areas: the Senegal Valley, the main rain fed areas, the imgated peri-urban horticulture, the oases and range lands have suffered heavy damages. About 170 communes out o f 192 have been affected and early projections indicate that crop losses may reach up to 50 percent on average, and 100 percent inmany areas o f highlyproductive agriculture. Total agricultural production may have decreased by 50 percent. There i s mounting evidence o f large scale distress sales o f livestock because o fthe lack o fpasture and fodder. Inaddition, the lack o f
91  adequate fodder for the livestock has induced the premature migration o fherds to the south, sometime through unusual routes, which will increase conflicts with local farmers.
Although the impact o f the invasion on national food security is still being estimated, there is no doubt that its impact at the household level will be devastating. Food prices, including that o fmeat andmilk, have already doubled over the last few weeks, as well as animal feed. Families inthe worst affected areas have lost up to 100percent o ftheir production. They are thus destitute andneed emergency assistance. It i s estimated that up to 8,000 farm families (800,000 persons) will need food aid as well as assistance to restore their productive assets andhave accessto transitory employment andincomeopportunities.
Finally, as demonstratedbyprevious infestations, the negative impact o f locust infestation i s not only short-term. It reverberates for a number o f years on the national economy because o fthe forced diversion o f scarce development resources to fighting the plague andthe wide- spread destruction o f productive assets. There i s thus a immediate need to (i) take all necessarymeasuresto suppress anderadicate locust swarms when they return inearly 2005, to prevent M e r damage and rural families being pushed into absolute poverty; and (ii) assist affected populations to restore their productive capacity. There i s also a need for buildingnational andregional capacities for locust surveillance, early warning, control and mitigation, as well more generally to develop more effective strategies and mechanisms for managing risks inrural areas.
11. GovernmentResponse, StrategyandProgram Government Strategy - The government o f Mauritania, because the country i s a perennial locust recession area, Inthe spring o f 2004, has always maintained a minimum capacity for early warning and prevention and control. The National Locust Control Center (NLCC) i s responsible for locust control operations. It.is adequately staffed and has developed a strategy based on permanent surveillance and prevention based on an extensive ground surveillance network (services o f the ministry o f agriculture and other ministries, rural communities and herders, the army), climatic and satellite information system, permanent effectivehntervention brigades (10). Incase o f infestation, the Center can call upon a number o f trained reserve teams located in government services throughout the country. During outbreaks, the NLCC i s transformed into a Central Command Center incharge o f coordinating control activities under a multi-sectoral Task Force headed by the Minister o f Rural Development. Finally, Mauritania maintain a permanentresearch center at Aioun which has been selected to become a regional center for locust research.
Response - The permanent control capacity allowed Mauritania to react quickly to the outbreaks in the fall o f 2003 and summer 2004. Domestic resources were quickly overwhelmed and the international support rapidly requested by the government was slow to mobilize. It (i) conducted extensive field surveys; (ii) out sensitizations carried and information campaigns for farmers and other stakeholders (press conferences, informatiodinstruction bulletins to the farming communities and the general public for the sighting andreporting o f DL); (iii) established 40 ground detectiodcontrol teams and mobilized 17 planes and 1 helicopter for aerial spraying' (v) mobilized farmers and
92  volunteers for ground brigades; (vi) mobilized the national army for logistics and ground operations; and (vii) acquired pesticides (600,000 l), spraying equipment (truck-mounted and man-carried), communication equipment and protective gears for the locust control teams. Finally, the government has organized weekly meetings with domestic and external partners to mobilize and efficiently coordinate the needed assistance. The government also designed a detailed operational program for Locust control and the restoration of agricultural assets and productivity in areas affected by locust invasion. This program was presented at the Locust control Meeting, held in July 2004 Dakar, Senegal. However, there was difficulties inquickly mobilizing the necessary logistics and financial resources for fighting the latter given its magnitude. As a result, control operations were inadequate in comparison with the magnitude o f the spring 2004 outbreak and, although they intensified considerably during the summer (field control operations increased from 3,000 to 34,000 hdday) and the outbreak couldn't be suppressed.
111. BankStrategy Bank assistance will support Government's overall program. It will be provided under the Bank's Emergency Procedures (OP/BP 8.50). It will provide support to Government's emergency Locust controVeradication operations, complementing the assistance provided by other donors but its main focus will be on (i) rehabilitationo fdestroyed assets and the productive capacities o f affected populations [and the provision o f alternative sources o f employment and revenues through cash-for-work publicly funded micro-projects and infrastructure programs]; and (ii) strengthening o f capacities for surveillance, early the warning systems and response mechanisms at national but also at regional levels, for reducing the risk and potential social, economic and environmental impact o f future infestations.
IV. The Project Description Overall Objectives - The overall objective o f the project i s to prevent or the minimize economic and social impact damage due to the current locust infestation, and to improve the national capacity to predict and control future infestations and mitigate its impact on the national economy and populations. The project i s fully in line with Mauritania poverty reduction strategy and rural developmental strategy. It i s also fully in line with NEPAD's Comprehensive African Agriculture Program (CAADP) which emphasizes betterdisaster preventiodmitigation andrisk management as one on the main instruments for growth andpoverty alleviation.
The project will be an integral part o f a national program funded by all donors in a coordinated fashion. It includes: (i) an emergency phase (2004-2005, funded by resources already mobilized and IDA'Sresources including those o f the PPF); and(ii) a medium-term program aimed a strengthening national and regional capacities for surveillance, early warning, response, mitigation, risk management and pesticide use and management. The progrdproject includes four components:
EmergencyLocust Management (controVeradication andpesticide management); Emergency Assistance to affectedpopulations;

The project, like government's overall program, will focus on areas particularly at risks on the basis o f the on-going detailed assessment and future information from the strengthened surveillance system. It has been designed on an emergency basis, on the basis o f available, sometime incomplete information. It is therefore likely that it will need to be adjusted to fit the actual evolution o f the situation on the ground. This will require the establishment from the start o f the program o f an efficient monitoring and evaluation system.

Carrying out immediate actual field controVeradicationoperations in early 2005, and2006 ifnecessary;
Improving the management o f pesticides through: a detailed inventory o f locust control pesticides (to ensure that no banned chemicals re imported or used); the safe transport, packaging, storage and destruction o f locust control pesticides, in accordance with international standards (International Code o f Conduct).
2. Component B - Emergency Assistance to Affected Populations - This component will provide assistance to affected populations for the restoration o f their productive capacity and the provision o f temporary employmenthncome earning opportunities:
(i) Restoration of productive capacity. 108  NIGEREMERGENCYLOCUSTPROJECT
I. ProjectBackground West Afiica i s facing its worst locust infestation in 15 years, spreading from the Atlantic coast to eastem Chad. The locust infestation was first predicted by FA0 inOctober 2003. Significant infestationbegan inearly 2004 inNorthwest Africa and has now spread to all Sahelian countries (Mauritania, Senegal, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, and Chad).
The first signs o f infestationinNiger were detected inearly 2003 inthe Northemregion o f the country. The DL infestation became worse in July 2004. About 224,000 ha were treated by the end o f October 2004. Despite the intensive control campaign, favorable conditions are still prevailing in the following parts o f the country: north (Air and Tamesna zones in Agadez region) and northwest (Tahoua region) and even west (northern pastoral zones inTillabery region). Therefore at the end o f October new hopper bands reinvaded the country. These hoppers could move toward Algeria, Libya, Chad and even north andwestem Sudan. It i s estimated that between July and October 2004, locust infestation has covered more than 750,000 ha and caused wide-spread crop and pasture losses.
Swarms are reproducing and migrating across borders following a so-called "circular migration" between North Africa and the Sahelian zone, which may cause multiple successive seasonal attacks over two to three years, as has happened in previous infestations. Niger i s highly likely to continue being affected by Desert Locust (DL) swarms that will start moving back Southward inthe winter and early spring o f 2005 and that at least 700,000 ha may have to be treated again in 2005 and possibly half that area in2006.
It is too early to have details o f crop and pasture losses. However, the recent FAO/ WFP/CILLS food security situation assessment estimated that up to 100,000 tons o f cereals may have been lost already due to the locust invasion (out o f a total shortfall of about 300,000 tons). This shortfall is also linked to the significant rain deficit experienced this year inthe country. There is mounting evidence oflarge scale distress sales oflivestockbecause o f the lack of pasture and fodder. Inaddition, the lack o f adequate fodder for livestock has induced the premature migration of herds to the south, sometime through unusual routes, which will increase conflicts with local fanners. Although the impact o f the invasion on national food security is still being estimated, there i s no doubt that its impact at the household level has been devastating. Families in the worst affected areas have lost up to 100% o f their production. They are thus destitute and need emergency assistance. It i s estimated that up to 150,000 households (1,000,000 persons) will need food aid as well as assistance to restore their productive assets and have access to transitory employment and
109  income opportunities.
Finally, as demonstrated byprevious infestations (1988, 1994), the negative impact o flocust infestation is not only short-term. It reverberates for a number o f years on the national economy because o f the forced diversion o f scarce development resources to fight the plague and the wide-spread destruction o f productive assets. There is thus an immediate need to (i) take all necessary measures to suppress and eradicate locust swarms as they return in early 2005 to prevent further damage and fixther rural families being pushed into absolute poverty; and (ii) help affected populations to restore their productive capacity. There i s also a need to build national and regional capacity for locust surveillance, early warning, control andmitigation, as well more generally to develop more effective strategies andmechanisms for managing risks inrural areas.
11. Government Response, Strategy and Program Government Strategy - The government o f Niger, with the support o f Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) and several other donors has taken early action for efficiently mobilizing domestic and external resources for controlling and suppressing the infestation. It (i) reorganized and strengthened the national Locus control system to cover adequately the infested areas (ii) re activated the existing"comite de concertation Etats- donateurs pour la securite alimentaire" chaired by the Prime Minister. This committee played a key role in mobilizing Government and donors; (iii) conducted assessment surveys to determine presence o f DL; (iv) carried out sensitizations campaigns for farmers, herders and other stakeholders (press conferences, informatiodinstruction bulletinsto the farmingcommunities and the general public for the sighting andreporting o f DL); (iv) established 9 ground detectiodcontrol teams and mobilized 3 planes for aerial campaign; (v) mobilized more than 11,500 farmers and volunteers for ground brigades; (vi) acquired and distributed 273,000 liters o f pesticides including its own stock. The national crops protection directorate ensures the coordination o f field operations and regularly reports to the above mentioned committee on weekly basis. The government also designed a detailed operational program for Locust control and the restoration o f agricultural assets and productivity in areas affected by locust invasion. This program was presented at the Locust control Meeting, heldinJuly 2004 Dakar.
111. Bank Strategy Bankassistance will support Government's overall program. Itwill beprovidedunder the Bank's Emergency Procedures (OPBP 8.50). It will provide support to Government's emergency Locust controVeradication operations, complementing the assistance provided by other donors but its main focus will be on (i) rehabilitation o fdestroyed assets and the productive capacities o f affected populations [andthe provision o f alternative sources o f employment and revenues through cash-for-work publicly funded micro-projects and infrastructure programs]; and (ii) strengthening o f capacities for surveillance, early the warning systems and response mechanisms at national but also at regional levels, for reducing the risk and potential social, economic and environmental impact o f future infestations.
110  IV. Project Description Overall Objectives - The overall objective o f the project i s to prevent or the minimize economic and social impact damage due to the current locust infestation, and to improve the national capacity to predict and control future infestations and mitigate its impact on the national economy and populations. The project is fully in line with The Niger poverty reduction strategy and rural developmental strategy. It i s also fully in line with NEPAD's Comprehensive African Agriculture Program (CAADP) which emphasizes better disaster preventiodmitigation andrisk management as one on the main instruments for growth andpoverty alleviation.
The project will be an integral part o f a national program funded by all donors in a coordinated fashion. It includes: (i)an emergency phase (2004-2005, funded by resources already mobilized and IDA'Sresources including those o fthe PPF); and (ii) a medium-tenn program aimed a strengthening national and regional capacities for surveillance, early waming, response, mitigation, risk management and pesticide use and management. The progradproject includes four components:
Emergency Locust Management (controVeradication and pesticide management); EmergencyAssistance to affected populations; Strengthening o f early warning and response capacities;' Project management
The project, like government's overall program, will focus on areas particularly at risks in 6 of 8 Niger regions. It has been designed on an emergency basis, on the basis of available, sometime incomplete information. It i s therefore likely that it will need to be adjusted to fit the actual evolution o f the situation on the ground. This will require the establishment from the start o f the program of an efficient monitoring and evaluation system.
Project Components The project will have the following four components:
1. Component A - Emergency Locust Management - This component will support government activities increasingthe national capacity for:
(0 Tracking locust infestation, including inneighboring countries;
(ii) Increasingquickresponsecapacityfor effectivecontroloperations ifan infestation does happen, as it appears likely, in the coming months: awarenesshnformation campaigns, training o f farming communities, transport and other equipment for locust detection and control brigades, emergency stocks o f pesticides, protection gear; telecommunication equipment, andrelated operating costs;
(iii) CarryingoutimmediateactualfieldcontroVeradicationoperationsinearly 2005, andpossibly in2006 ;
111  (iv) Improving the management o f pesticides through: a detailed inventory o f locust control pesticides (to ensure that no banned chemicals re imported or used); the safe transport, packaging, storage and destruction o f locust control pesticides, in accordance with international standards (International Code o f Conduct).
2. Component B - Emergency Assistance to Affected Populations - This component will provide assistance to affected populations for the restoration o f their productive capacity and the provision o f temporary employment/income earning opportunities:
(i) Restoration of productive capacity. This will be done through several approaches, based on careful targeting, depending on the specific characteristics o f the concerned areas and populations: through in kind assistance --distribution o f ((starter packs))o f inputs (seeds, fertilizers, tools, animal feed, etc.)-where necessary; through distribution o f a cash allowance corresponding to the estimated cost o f the inputs necessary for resuming production (allowing beneficiaries to decide what to purchase and where);
(ii) Provision of alternative employment opportunities. This will be done to provide affected populations with temporary income opportunities while normal income streams are restored through locally planned and managed cash for work programs targeted at collective infrastructure (feeder roads, dams/irrigation/drainage, bottomland development, land management for collective trees plantingactivities).
3. Component C - Strengthening o f early Warning and Response Capacities - This component will support the strengthening o f national and regional capacities for locust infestation surveillance, control and mitigation; and the preparation o f national and regional strategies for the management o f natural disasterdrisks in rural areas. Specifically, it will support:
(9 The sensitization and training o f fanning communities/groups to locust and other pest detection and control;
(ii) Thestrengthening ofthenationalpestmanagement services (additional human resources, constructionhehabilitation o f facilities, specialized equipment) to ensure minimum efficiency and viability during remission periods and an adequate quick response capability incase o f emergency;
(iii) The implementation of a strengthened research program on locust biological control and IPM, carried out through the national agricultural research system (IER) but also through participation (researchers, financial) in joint regional research programs carried out under CORAF coordination;
112  (iv) The preparation o f a comprehensive national natural risk managementhlnerability reduction strategy to be integrated into Niger's overall PRSP and rural development strategy; and
(v) The participation in collective activities at regional level such as an operationaVinstitutiona1audit o f the current regional system for locust and other pest management systems aimed at improving their efficiency and sustainability; and the design o f a regional mechanism for natural disaster risk management inrural areas (based on close integration between local, national and regional instruments).
4. Component D - Project Coordination and Management - The component will support the cost o f project management unit (office rehabilitation and equipment, short-term consultancies, incremental operating costs), including financial and technical audits, and participation in coordination meetings at the regional level. It will inparticular finance the design, establishment and operations o f a comprehensive monitoring and evaluation system (including economic, social and environmental impacts as well as cross boundaries issues) based on and fully integrated with existing institutional and M $ E systems.
Expected Outputs and Impact - The overall achievement o f the project will be monitored through the following (outputhmpact) performance indicators.
The total cost includes the cost o f short-term activities which have been funded by the PPF granted by IDA on September 22, 2004 which has also been used for the detailed preparation o f Government's medium-term program presented below. It will be refinanced under Bank's credit.
The project is part o f government's overall program. It has been designed, on an emergency basis, on the basis o f available information regarding (i) the magnitude o f actual and projected infestations and affected populations; (ii) the already mobilized and committed financial support. It i s therefore likely that both its detailed design and its fundingwill needto be adjusted to fit the actual evolution o f the situation on the ground, and additional financial resources that may become available. Its estimated cost includes important physical contingencies. Readjustments in the program's emphasis and detailed content, and reallocations o f funds between components, will be done every yeadas necessary inclose cooperation with all funding partners, on the basis o f actual needs and developments on the ground (as tracked by the monitoring and evaluation system that will be established from the start o f the program). Un-necessaryhnused funds from the IDA credit will be cancelledat the end o fthe project.
Other Funding- Other funding has been provided by: FA0 US$300.000; AfDB UC2,5 million; EU 2,5 million euros and about US$4 million. Total contributions received to date from domestic partners to date include amount in cash, fuel and pesticides at national level amounts.
113  Project Implementation - The Ministry o f Agriculture will be responsible for project implementation. The project is o f a multi-sectoral nature and it will be implemented under the guidance o f a steering committee chaired by the " Secretaire General du Ministere de 1' Agriculture". The steering committee will include the " Cellule Crise Alimentaire" in which the main donors are represented, representatives from farmers Organizations and NGOs. A Project Coordinator will be appointed within the Secretariat o f Agriculture to manage and coordinate the activities o f the Project. The Project Coordinator will be responsible for (i) preparing detailed implementation plans and budgets, (ii)discussing these plans and budgets with participating donors; (iii) supervising implementation activities; (iv) coordinating with regional institutions; and (v) and reporting on the use o f resources and results achieved. The financial management and procurement activities will be implemented under the Community Action Program (CAP)) which i s already established andoperating according to procedures satisfactory to IDA. The PC will be responsible for coordinating the support o f all external donors, ensuring coherence and transparence inthe use o f all available resources, and for timely and accurate reporting.
The Project will be implemented through existing institutions and usedfor strengthening the national institutional framework. Local communities/populations will be closely associated to the planning, implementation and monitoring o f its activities. For the implementation o f its activities, the project will collaborate with various national partners (Department o f Agricultural Services, National Agricultural Research Institute, National Environment Agency, Department o f Planning, Department o f Health Services, N o n Governmental Organizations and the Department o f Cooperatives) as well as with institutions in other countries and relevant regional institutions for collective actions concerning regional public goods. This i s inparticular the case for the proposed research program which will be implemented with the national research institute and within a regional CORAF network and insynergy with a CORAF member international institute.
Particular attention will be given to the detailed mechanism for targeting project assistance to affectedpopulations andto the monitoring o f efficient delivery. The detailed Project/program Implementation Plan (PIP), including the detailed targeting system, and Monitoring and Evaluation System (M&E) will be agreed upon and established at project.
As already mentioned, the project i s part o f government's overall locust emergency management program, and has been designed on the basis o f available information and best estimates regarding the future evolution o f the infestation and its impact on agricultural communities. Relative emphasis among components and related finding requirements will need to be regularly adjusted to fit with the actual evolution o f the situation on the ground, and additional financial resources that maybecome available,
Disbursement Arrangements Disbursement - All costs are inclusive o f taxes and duties. Government o f Niger will finance 100percent o f (i) and duties (estimated at a rate o f 20%).The disbursement taxes
114  schedule is expected to be as follows: about 80 percent o f the IDA Credit i s expected to be disbursed during IDA fiscal year 2005; 12 percent during fiscal year 2006, 4 percent duringfiscal year 2007 and4 percent duringfiscal year 2008.
Special Account - The project will have only one Special Account. This Special Account opened in a commercial bank acceptable to IDA, will be operated in accordance with the Bank's operational guidelines.
Disbursements from IDA will be initially made on the basis o f incurred eligible expenditures (transaction based disbursements). To expedite implementation, IDA will make an advance disbursement from the proceeds of the Credit by depositing it into a Borrower-operated Special Account. The advance to the Special Account will be used to finance IDA's share o f expenditures under the proposed Credit. Another acceptable method o f withdrawing funds from the Credit is the direct payment method, involving direct payments from the Credit to a third party for works, goods and services upon the Borrower's request. Payments may also be made to a commercial bank for expenditures against IDA special commitments covering a commercial bank's Letter o f Credit. IDA's Disbursement Letter stipulates a minimum application value for direct payment and special commitment procedures.
To facilitate disbursements for eligible expenditures for goods, work and services, upon credit effectiveness, the PMU will be required to submit a withdrawal application for an initial deposit to the special account, drawn from the IDA Credit, in an amount not to exceed CFAF500,000,000 covering an estimated four months o f eligible o f expenditures financed by IDA. Upon credit effectiveness, IDA will deposit the amount o f CFAF250,000,000 into the Special Account, representing approximately fifty percent of the authorized allocation. The remaining balance will be made available when the aggregate amount of withdrawals from the credit account plus the total amount of all outstanding special commitments entered into by the Association shall be equal or exceed the equivalent of SDR3,000,000. Replenishment o f funds from IDA to the special account will be made upon evidence o f satisfactory utilization of the advance, reflected in SOEs (Statement of Expenditures) and/or on full documentation for payments above SOE thresholds. The special account will be used for all payments below twenty percent o fthe authorized allocation and replenishment applications will be required to be submitted on a monthly basis. Ifineligible expenditures are found to have been made from the special account, the Borrower will be obligated to refund the amounts withdrawn. Ifthe special account remains inactive for more than six months, IDA may request the Borrower to refknd the amounts advanced to the special account.
IDA will have the right, as reflected inthe Development Credit Agreement, to suspend disbursement of the funds, ifreporting requirements are not complied with.
Use of statements of expenditure - The following expenses can be submitted on a SOE basis: (a) contracts with an estimated value o f less than US$500,000 for works; (b) contracts with an estimated value o f less than US$250,000 for equipment and goods; (c) contracts with an estimated value o f less than US$lOO,OOO for consulting firms and less
115  than US$50,000 for individual consultants; and (e) training, Micro-Grants and incremental operating expenses which may be claimed on the basis o f SOEs. Documentation supporting all expenditures claimed against SOEs will be retained by PMU, andwill be available for review when requested by IDA supervision missions and auditors. All disbursements are subject to the conditions o f the Development Credit Agreement andthe procedures definedinthe Disbursement Letter.
All application for the withdrawal o f proceeds from the credit will be fully documented for expenditures for Pesticide, regardless o f the amount.
When project implementationbegins, the quarterly financial Monitoring Reports (FMRs) produced by the project will be reviewed. Strengthening its accounting and financial management capacity will enable PMU to establish effective financial management and accounting systems, which should facilitate to produce the Financial Monitoring Report (FMR). Where the reports are adequate and produced on a timely basis, and a borrower requests conversion to report-based disbursements, a review will be undertaken by the Task Team Leader (TTL), to determine if the project i s eligible. The adoption o f report- based disbursements by the project will enable it to move away from time consuming voucher by voucher.
Disbursement Conditions - No withdrawals shall be made in respect of: (a) payments made for expenditures prior to the date o f this Agreement; (b) payments made under category (3),(i) unless the Borrower has furnished to the Association a Pest Management Plan in form and substance satisfactory to the Association, and (ii) the purchase o f for pesticides not included in the Authorized Pesticides List; and (c) payments made under category (6), unless Micro-Grants have been made in accordance with the provisions set forth or referredto inthe Project ImplementationPlanandthe provisions o fparagraph 13 o f Schedule 4 o fthe Development Credit Agreement.
Project account - This account will be opened in a commercial bank acceptable to IDA. Counterpart funds will be deposited regularly in this account in accordance with project needs. To facilitate disbursements for eligible expenditures for goods, works and services, upon project effectiveness, the government would be required to make a deposit into the project account o f CFAF30,000,000 covering an estimated six months o f eligible expenditures co-financed bythe government.

Documents related to procurement below the prior review thresholds will be maintained bythe Borrower for ex-post review by auditors andIDAsupervisionmissions.
The PIU will work closely with the all the other partners involved in the project implementation. The CAP will also be primarily responsible for reporting on Project progress, financial management, procurement and disbursement, identifying implementation gaps and bottlenecks, and managingProject accounts and budget.
Manual of Procedures. The financial and administrative manual in use by the CAP will be adapted as needed inorder to respond to the specificity o f the Locust Project.
Procurementpackagepreparation. All procurement package s will be prepared bythe Procurement Specialist o fthe PIU. All procurement will be carried out inaccordance with the procurementplan and as agreedwith the Bank.

I. ProjectBackground West Africa i s facing its worst locust infestation in 15 years, spreading from the Atlantic coast to eastern Chad. The locust infestation was first predicted by FA0 inOctober 2003. Significant infestationbegan inearly 2004 inNorthwest Africa andhas now spread to all Sahelian countries (Mauritania, Senegal, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger and Chad).
The first signs of infestation in Senegal were detected in June 2004 in the Northem region o f the country. It i s estimated that between June and October 2004, locust infestation covered more than 920,000 ha where it caused wide-spread crop and pasture losses in eight o f the eleven regions o f the country. Swarms are reproducing and migrating across borders following a so-called "circular migration" between North Africa and the Sahelian zone, which may cause multiple successive seasonal attacks over two to three years as has happened inprevious infestations. Senegal is likely to be affected again by Desert Locust (DL) swarms that will start moving back Southward inthe winter and early spring o f 2005 and at least 600,000 ha may have to be treated again in 2005 and possibly halfthat area in2006.
It is too early to have precise estimates o f crop and pasture losses so far. However, it is already estimated that up to 320,000 tons o f cereals may have been lost already due to the locust invasion. There i s mounting evidence o flarge scale distress sales o f livestock because o f the lack o f pasture and fodder. Inaddition, the lack o f adequate fodder for livestock has induced the premature migration o f herds to the south, sometime through unusual routes, which will increase conflicts with local farmers. Although the impact o f the invasion on national food security i s still being estimated, there i s no doubt that its impact at the household level has been devastating. Because o f the specific characteristics o f locust damage. Families inthe worst affected areas have lost up to 70 percent o f their production and are thus destitute. It is estimated that up to 10percent rural households will be affected and therefore will need food aid as well as assistanceto restore their productive assets and have access to transitory employment andincome opportunities.
Finally, as demonstratedbypreviousinfestations (1988, 1994), the negative impact o f locust infestation is not only short-term. It reverberates for a number o f years on the national economy because o f the forced diversion o f scarce development resources to fight the plague and the wide-spread destruction o f productive assets. There i s thus an immediate need to (i) take all necessary measures to suppress and eradicate locust swarms as they return in early 2005 to prevent fkther damage and more rural families being pushed into absolute poverty; and (ii) help affected populations to restore their productive capacity. There is also a need to build national and regional capacity for locust surveillance, early
128  warning, control, andmitigation, as well more generally to develop more effective strategies andmechanisms for managingrisks inruralareas.
11. Government Response, Strategy and Program Government Strategy - In June 2004, on the basis o f the lessons learned and following consultations with the Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO), the Government o f Senegal has taken early action for efficiently mobilizing domestic and external resources for controlling and suppressing the infestation. It (i)established a National Locust Control Committee, chaired by the Minister o f Agriculture, to coordinate government action and mobilize resources; (ii) conducted surveys to determine presence o f DL; (iii) carried out sensitizations campaigns for farmers and other stakeholders (press conferences, informatiodinstruction bulletins to the farming communities and the general public for the sighting and reporting o f DL); (iv) established 50 ground detectiodcontrol teams and mobilized 20 planes for aerial spraying' (v) mobilized farmers through about 2800 locust control village committees; (vi) mobilized the national army for logistics and ground operations; and (vii) acquired (521,000 liters and 414 tons) and distributed (43 1,000 liters and 324 tons) pesticides, spraying equipment (53 truck-mounted and 1,500 man-carried), communication equipment and protective gears for the locust control teams. In each region of the country operational command posts headed by the Regional Governor coordinated field operations. Finally, the government has organized weekly meetings with domestic and external partners: FAO, UNDP, EU, Ambassadors, international development institutions, NGOs, the public andprivate sectors -to mobilize and efficiently coordinate the needed assistance. The government also designed a detailed emergency action plan for Locust control and the restoration o f agricultural assets and productivity in areas affected by locust invasion. Mali hosted the second Agriculture Ministers Conference was held in July 2004 Dakar, and addressed in particular Locust control regional issues. As a result, control activities have intensified and it i s estimated that more than 600,000 hectares o f infested landhave so far been treated. The infestation has beentemporarily brought under control,
111. Bank Strategy Bank assistancewill support Government's overall program. It will be provided under the Bank's Emergency Procedures (OP/BP 8.50). It will provide support to Government's emergency Locust controVeradication operations, complementing the assistance provided by other donors but its mainfocus will be on (i) rehabilitation o f destroyed assets and the productive capacities o f affected populations and the provision o f alternative sources o f employment and revenues through cash-for-work publicly funded micro-projects and infrastructure programs; and (ii) the strengthening o f capacities for surveillance, early warning systems and response mechanisms at national but also at regional levels, for reducing the risk and potential social, economic and environmental impact o f future infestations.
IV. Project Description Overall Objectives - The overall objective o f the project is to prevent or the minimize economic and social impact damage due to the current locust infestation, and to improve
129  the national capacity to predict and control future infestations and mitigate its impact on the national economy and populations. The project is fully in line with the Senegal poverty reduction strategy and rural developmental strategy. It i s also fully in line with NEPAD's Comprehensive African Agriculture Program (CAADP) which emphasizes better disaster preventiodmitigation andrisk management as one on the main instruments for growth andpoverty alleviation.
The project will be an integral part o f a national program funded by all donors in a coordinated fashion. It includes: (i) an emergency phase (2004-2005, funded by resources already mobilized and IDA'Sresources including those o f the PPF); and (ii) a medium-term program aimed a strengthening national and regional capacities for surveillance, early warning, response, mitigation, risk management andpesticideuse andmanagement. The proposed projectwould includefour components:
0 Emergency Locust control andpesticide management; 0 Restoration o f agriculture productive capacities and emergency assistance to affectedpopulations; Strengthening o f capacities inforecasting, early warning, response and mitigation (including regional cooperation); 0 Programmanagement.
The project, like government's overall program, will focus on areas particularly at risks inthe eight affected regions. It has beendesignedon an emergency basis, on the basis of available, sometime incomplete information. It i s therefore likely that it will need to be adjusted to fit the actual evolution o f the situation on the ground. This will require the establishment from the start o f the program o f an efficient monitoring and evaluation system.
ProjectComponents The project will have the following four components:
1. Component A - Emergency Locust Control - This component will support government activities increasing the national capacity for:
(i) Increasing quick response capacity for effective emergency control operations: awarenesdinformation campaigns, training o f farming communities, transport and other equipment for locust detection and control brigades, emergency stocks o f pesticides, protection gear, telecommunication equipment, and related emergency operating costs;
(ii)Improvingthemanagementofpesticidesthrough:adetailedinventoryof Locust control pesticides (to ensure that no banned chemicals re imported or used); the safe transport, packaging, storage and destruction o f Locust control pesticides and containers, in accordance with international standards (International Code o f Conduct);
130  (iii)Ecotoxicmonitoringandimpactevaluationofspraying,andmitigation.
2. Component B - Restoration o f Populations Productive Capacities -This component will provide assistanceto potentially affected populations through:
the carrying out o f a detailed production losses assessment and the development o f targeting mechanisms;
the restorationo fthe seedproduction capacity o f the Bambey station;
the distribution o f ((starter packs ))o f inputs (seeds, fertilizers, tools, animal feed, etc.) to maintainhestore the productive capacities o f the affected farmers and herders; and
the undertaking o f labor intensive collective productive micro-projects (dams, irrigatioddrainage, bottomland development), to provide alternative sources o f employment and cash revenues until the normal income streams are restored.
3. Component C - Strengthening o f National Capacities - This component will support the strengthening o f national capacities, and o f the regional capacities for undertaking collective action. specifically, it will support:
surveillance/early warning, control and mitigation o f locust infestations, including inneighboring countries;
the sensitization andtraining o f farming communities/groups to locust/pest detection and control;
the complementary equipment o f the national pest management services (constructionhehabilitation o f facilities, specialized equipment, in particular for the Richard Toll station) and the training, o f its staff;
the implementation o f research and development programs on Locust biological control and IPM, inparticular through participation into ajoint regional researchprogram under C O W .
4. Component D- Project Management and Coordination - The component will support:
(i) the cost o f project coordinating unit (office rehabilitation and equipment, short-term consultancies, incrementaloperating costs);
(ii) financialandtechnicalaudits;
(iii) training, workshops, study tours, and coordination meetings at the regional level;
131  (iv) the design, establishment and operations o f a comprehensive Government program monitoring and evaluation system (including economic, social and environmental impacts as well as cross boundaries issues) based on and fully integratedwith existing institutional and M&E systems;
(v) technical assistance and studies to: (i) develop a comprehensive national natural risk management/vulnerabilityreduction system for the rural sector to be integrated into the Senegal overall PRSP and rural development strategy; and (ii)strengthen the close integration o f national programs/activities into the regional framework for locust and other pest management systems.
The total cost includes the cost o f short-term activities which have been fimded by the PPF granted by IDA on September 22,2004. The PPF has also beenused for the detailed preparation of Government's medium-term program presented below. It will be refinanced under Bank's credit.
The project i s part o f government's overall program. It has been designed, on an emergency basis, on the basis o f available information regarding (i) magnitude o f the actual and projected infestations and affected populations; (ii) the already mobilized and committed financial support. It is therefore likely that both its detailed design and its fimdingwill need to be adjusted to fit the actual evolution o fthe situation on the ground, and additional financial resources that may become available. Its estimated cost includes important physical contingencies. Readjustments inthe program's emphasis and detailed content, and reallocations o f funds between components, will be done every yeadas necessary in close cooperation with all fundingpartners, on the basis o f actual needs and developments on the ground (as tracked by the monitoring and evaluation system that will be established from the start o f the program). Project Implementation. The Ministry o f Agriculture will be responsible for project implementation. The project is o f a multi-sectoral nature and it will be implemented under the guidance o f the National Locust Control Committee which be enlarged to include representatives from rural elected bodies and the civil society. A Project Coordinator will be appointed within the Department o f Plant Protection to manage and coordinate the activities o f the Project. The Project Coordinator will be responsible for (i)

The financial management and procurement activities will be managed bythe PSAOPFiduciary Unit at the Ministryo fFinance which is already established and operating according to procedures satisfactory to IDA. The PC will be responsible for coordinating the support o f all external donors, ensuring coherence and transparence in the use o f all available resources, and for timely and accurate reporting. The responsibilities and accountability o f the Project Coordinator will be detailed in a performance contract agreed uponwith the Inter-Ministerial Locust Control Committee.
Particular attention will be given to the detailed mechanism for targeting project assistanceto affected populations and to the monitoring o f efficient delivery. The detailed Project/program Implementation Plan (PIP), including the detailed targeting system, and Monitoring and Evaluation System (M&E) will be agreed upon and established at the start o fproject.
It will be implemented through existing institutions and used for strengthening the national institutional framework. Local communities/populations will be closely associated to the planning, implementation and monitoring o f its activities. For the implementation of its activities, the project will collaborate with various national partners (National Agricultural Research Institutes, National Environment Agency, Department o f Planning, Department o f Health Services, Non Governmental Organizations, ANCAR, and ASPRODEP) as well as with institutions in other countries and relevant regional institutions for collective actions concerning regional public goods. This i s inparticular the case for the proposed research and development program to promote Locust control bio-pesticides and IPMapproaches.
As already mentioned, the project is part o f government's overall locust emergency management program, and has been designed on the basis o f available information and best estimates regardingthe future evolution o fthe infestation evolution and its impact on agricultural communities. Relative emphasis among components and related hnding requirements will need to be regularly adjusted to fit with the actual evolution o f the situation on the ground, and additional financial resources that may become available. To this effect, the project coordinator will prepare detailed programs, budgets and financing plans every 6 months for discussion with the program Steering Committee and the donors fundinggovernment's program.

148  THE GAMBIAEMERGENCYLOCUST PROJECT
I. ProjectBackground West Africa is facing its worst locust infestation in 15 years, spreading from the Atlantic coast to eastern Chad. The locust infestation was first predictedby FA0inOctober 2003. Significant infestation beganinearly 2004 inNorthwest Africa and has now spread to all Sahelian countries (Mauritania, Senegal, Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, and Chad.
After a late start, at least in Sahelian countries, control operations have intensified over the summer and it is estimated that more than 2 million ha o f infested land have so far been treated. As a result, the infestation has been suppressed and the situation has improved in the Southern areas o f the Sahel where vegetation is rapidly drying up. Numerous swarms have left andmovednorth into northwest Mauritania, Western Sahara, and the foothills o f the Atlas mountains in Morocco and Algeria where intensive aerial and ground control operations were immediately initiated. Other swarms have moved to the Cape Verde islands, northernMali andNiger, and southern Algeria.
The Gambia has so far been spared o f any infestation, and the danger appears to be receding for the remainder o f 2004 period. However, swarms are reproducing and migrating across borders following a so-called "circular migration" betweenNorthAfrica andthe Sahelian zone, which may cause multiple successive seasonal attacks over two to three years as has happened in previous infestations. It is already predicted that swarms will move back to the Southern part o fthe Sahelian zone inthe winter and early springo f 2005 and there i s a significant risk that the infestation will reach The Gambia as well as the Northernparts o f Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, C6te d'Ivoire, andNigeria.
The Gambia i s mostly likely to be affected by Desert Locust (DL) swarms that become involved in the so-called Southern Circuit migration. This occurs during the late winter period when a portion o f the swarms that have re-formed inthe Sahel (Mauritania- Chad) move first west then south into Senegal and The Gambia. This movement can start around November and continues into February/April2005, which will be the most critical period for The Gambia.
In 1988, The Gambia experienced a devastating Desert Locust invasion. The country was totally unprepared to control the upsurge which resulted in severe economic damage and crop losses and destroyed the productive assets of a large number o f poor agricultural families, pushing them hrther into poverty, Again during the 1992-1994 regional outbreak, swarms invaded The Gambia in February 1994,and, although the infestation was less severe than in 1988, caused significant damage and crop losses, again due to a lack o f institutional andhuman resource capacities.
149  The most urgent action required now i s to strengthen national capacity (capacity building for all stakeholders in monitoring and control in case o f attacks to provide emergency assistance to affected farmers to recover their crop losses) combined with sub-regional intervention mechanisms for aerial sprayingbases ineach country.
I1 Government Response, Strategy and Program Government Strategy - In May 2004, on the basis o f the lessons learned and following consultations with FAO, the government took early action to ensure that the country was ready to address any possible invasion and suppress it before it could develop. It established a National Food Security and Disaster Relief Committee chaired by Her Excellency, the Vice President, to coordinate government action and mobilize resources. The committee (i)conducted assessment surveys to determine presence o f DL; (ii) conducted sensitization and training for farmers and other stakeholders (press conferences, informationhnstruction bulletins to the farming communities and the general public for the sighting and reporting o f DL); (iii)established fifteen Locust Campaign Teams and the general campaign structure (information centers, central technical committee, divisional task forces, district and village farmer brigades; (iv) distributed pesticides, equipment and protective gears to the locust control teams; and (v) held consultative meetings with FAO, UNDP, EU, Ambassadors, NGOs, the public and private sectors and submitted proposals to donors for assistances. The Gambia Government also reviewed its Locust Control Strategy and adopted a detailed operational program for Locust control and the restoration o f agricultural assets and productivity in areas affected by locust invasion. This program was the Locust control Meeting, held in July 2004 inDakar, Senegal.
Support by Domestic and External Partners - It i s estimated that the cost o f Government short term preparedness activities (until end-December 2004) described above will amount to US$2,0555, 706.3. Total contributions received from domestic partners to date amount in cash, fuel and pesticides at national level amounts to D6, 860, 500 . The FA0 has provided US$ 160,000, the UnitedStates Government US$ 50,000 and UNDP US$ 50,000. Government contribution i s estimated at 10% o f project cost in kind contribution. Details of individual donations are shown at Annex 1. The projected financial gap for supported short-term activities has been funded by a PPF granted by IDA on 22 September2004. The PPF has also been used for the detailed preparation o f Government's medium-term program presentedbelow.
111. BankStrategy Bank assistancewill support Government's overall program. It will be provided under the Bank's Emergency Procedures (OPBP 8.50). It will provide support to Government's emergency Locust controlleradication operations, complementing the assistance provided by other donors but its main focus will be on (i) rehabilitation o f destroyed assets and the productive capacities of affected populations; and (ii) the strengthening o f capacities for surveillance, early warning systems and response mechanisms at national but also at regional levels, for reducing the risk and potential social, economic and environmental impact o f future infestations.
150  IV. Project Description Overall Objectives - The overall objective o f the project i s to prevent or the minimize economic and social impact damage due to the current locust infestation, and to improve the national capacity to predict and control future infestations and mitigate its impact on the national economy and populations. The project is fully in line with The Gambia poverty reduction strategy and rural developmental strategy. It i s also hlly in line with NEPAD's Comprehensive African Agriculture Program (CAADP) which emphasizes better disaster preventiodmitigation and risk management as one on the main instruments for growth andpoverty alleviation.
Project Components The project will have the following four components:
1. Component A - Emergency Locust Control - This component will support government activities increasing the national capacity for:
Tracking locust infestation, including inneighboring countries;
Increasing quick response capacity for effective control operations if an infestation does happen, as it aprks likely, in the coming months: awarenesshnformation campaigns, training o f farming communities, transport and other equipment for locust detection and control brigades, emergency stocks o f pesticides, protection gear; telecommunication equipment, andrelated operating costs;
Carrying out immediate actual field control/eradication operations should an outbreak materialize inearly 2005 ;
Improving the management o f pesticides through: a detailed inventory o f Locust control pesticides (to ensure that no banned chemicals re imported or used); the safe transport, packaging, storage and destruction o f Locust control pesticides, in accordance with international standards (International Code o f Conduct).
2. Component B - Restoration o f Populations Productive Capacities - This component will provide assistance to potentially affected populations through:
(i) The distribution o f ((starter packs)) o f inputs (seeds, fertilizers, tools, animal feed, etc.) to maintaidrestore the productive capacities o f the affected farmers andherders; and
(ii) The undertaking o f cash for work program or collective productive micro- projects (dams, irrigatioddrainage, bottomland development), to provide alternative sources o f employment and revenues until the normal income streams are restored.
151  3. Component C - Strengthening o f National Capacities - This component will support the strengthening o f national capacities, and o f the regional capacities for undertaking collective action, for surveillance/early warning, control and mitigation of locust (and other pests) infestations. Specifically, it will support:
The sensitization and training o f farming communities/groups to locust/pest detection and control;
The complementary equipment o f the national pest management services (constructionhehabilitation o f facilities, specialized equipment) and the training, o f its staff;
The implementation o f a strengthened research program on Locust biological control and IPM, inparticular through participation into a joint regional research program under C O W ;
Short-term technical assistance and studies to: develop a comprehensive national natural risk managementhlnerability reduction strategy to be integrated into The Gambia's overall PRSP and rural development strategy; and strengthen the close integration o f national programdactivities into the regional framework for locust and other pest management systems
4. Component D - Project Management and Coordination - The component will support the cost o f project management unit (office rehabilitation and equipment, short-term consultancies, incremental operating costs), including financial and technical audits, and participation in coordination meetings at the regional level. It will in particular finance the design, establishment and operations o f a comprehensive program monitoring and evaluation system (including economic, social and environmental impacts as well as cross boundaries issues) based on and fully integratedwith existing institutional andM$Esystems.
IDA financing will represent 70 percent o f the total cost of government program. Other funding will be provided by: Government; FAO; AfDB; EU; at about 30 percent The program has beendesignedon an emergency basis, on the basis o f available information. It i s therefore likelythat it will needto be adjusted to fit the actual evolution o fthe situation on the ground. Its estimated cost includes important physical contingencies. Readjustments in the program's emphasis and detailed content, and reallocations o f funds between components, will be done every year/as necessary in close cooperation with all funding partners, on the basis of actual needs and developments on the ground (as tracked by the monitoring and evaluation system that will be established from the start o f the program). Un-necessaryhused funds from the IDAcredit will be cancelled at the endo fthe project.
Project Implementation - The Department o f State for Agriculture will be responsible for project implementation. The project is o f a multi-sectoral nature and it will be implemented under the guidance o f the National Food Security and Disaster Relief Committee which includes representatives from all related sectors health, environment,
152  agriculture, NGOs, CBOs, and farmer organizations and the civil society. A Project Coordinator will be appointed within the Department o f Plant Protection to manage and coordinate the activities o f the Project. The Project Coordinator will be responsible for (i) preparing detailed implementation plans and budgets, (ii) supervising implementation activities; and (iii)and reporting on the use o f resources and results achieved. The financial management and procurement activities will be managed by the Capacity Building Economic Management Project (CBEMP) which is already established and operating according to procedures satisfactory to IDA. The PC will be responsible for coordinating the support o f all external donors, ensuring coherence and transparence in the use o f all available resources, and for timely and accurate reporting.
It will be implemented through existing institutions and used for strengthening the national institutional framework. Local communities/populations will be closely associated to the planning, implementation and monitoring o f its activities. For the implementation of its activities, the project will collaborate with various national partners (Department of Agricultural Services, National Agricultural Research Institute, National Environment Agency, Department o f Planning, Department o f Health Services, The Gambia College, Non Governmental Organizations and the Department o f Cooperatives) as well as with institutions in other countries and relevant regional institutions for collective actions concerningregional public goodshads. This i s inparticular the case for the proposedresearch program which involves adoption o f alternatives to agro-pesticides and other agricultural best practices inthe sub-region. (elaborate)
Disbursement Arrangements Disbursement - All costs are inclusive o f taxes and duties. Government o f The Gambia will finance 100 percent of: (i) and duties (estimated at a rate o f 30 percent). The taxes disbursement schedule i s expected to be as follows: about 90 percent o f the IDA Credit i s expected to be disbursed during IDA fiscal year 2005; 4 percent during fiscal year 2006, 3 percent during fiscal year 2007 and 3 percent during fiscal year 2008.
Special Account - The project will have only one special account. This special account, which should be opened in a commercial bank acceptable to IDA, will be operated in accordance with the Bank's operational guidelines.
Disbursements from IDA will be initially made on the basis o f incurred eligible expenditures (transaction based disbursements). To expedite implementation, IDA will make an advance disbursement from the proceeds o f the Credit by depositing it into a Borrower-operated special account. The advance to the special account will be used to finance IDA's share o f expenditures under the proposed Credit. Another acceptable method o f withdrawing funds from the Credit i s the direct payment method, involving direct payments from the Credit to a third party for works, goods and services upon the Borrower's request. Payments may also be made to a commercial bank for expenditures against IDA special commitments covering a commercial bank's Letter o f Credit. IDA's Disbursement Letter stipulates a minimum application value for direct payment and special commitment procedures.
153  To facilitate disbursements for eligible expenditures for goods, work and services, upon credit effectiveness, the PMUwill be required to submit a withdrawal application for an initial deposit to the Special Account, drawn from the IDA Credit, in an amount not to exceed US$200,000 covering an estimated four months o f eligible o f expenditures financed by IDA. Replenishment o f funds from IDA to the special account will be made upon evidence o f satisfactory utilization o f the advance, reflected in SOEs (Statement o f Expenditures) and/or on full documentation for payments above SOE thresholds. The special account will be used for all payments below twenty percent of the authorized allocation and replenishment applications will be required to be submitted on a monthly basis. If ineligible expenditures are found to have been made from the special account, the Borrower will be obligated to refund the amounts withdrawn. If the special account remains inactive for more than six months, IDA may request the Borrower to refundthe amounts advanced to the special account.
IDA will have the right, as reflected inthe Development Credit Agreement, to suspend disbursement o f the funds, ifreporting requirements are not complied with.
Use of statements of expenditure - All application for the withdrawal o f proceeds from the credit will be fully documented except for (a) contracts with an estimated value o f less than US$500,000 for works; (b) contracts with an estimated value o f less than US$250,000 for equipment and goods; (c) contracts with an estimated value o f less than US$lOO,OOO for consulting firms and less thanUS$50,000 for individual consultants; and (e) training, Micro-Grants and incremental operating expenses which may be claimed on the basis o f SOEs. Documentation supporting all expenditures claimed against SOEs will be retainedby PMU, and will be available for review when requested by IDA supervision missions and auditors. All disbursements are subject to the condition of the Development Credit Agreement andthe procedures defined inthe Disbursement Letter.
All application for the withdrawal o f proceeds from the credit will be fully documented for expenditures for Pesticide, regardless o fthe amount. Whenproject implementationbegins, the quarterlyFinancialMonitoringReports (FMRs) produced by the project will be reviewed. Strengthening its accounting and financial management capacity will enable PMU to establish effective financial management and accounting systems, which should facilitate to produce the Financial Monitoring Report (FMR).Where the reports are adequate and produced on a timely basis, and a borrower requests conversion to report-based disbursements, a review will be undertaken by the Task Team Leader (TTL), to determine if the project is eligible. The adoption o f report- based disbursements by the project will enable it to move away from time consuming voucher by voucher.
Disbursement Conditions - No withdrawals shall be made in respect of: (a) payments made for expenditures prior to the date of this Agreement; (b) payments made under category (3),(i) unless the Borrower has furnished to the Association a Pest Management Plan in form and substance satisfactory to the Association, and (ii) the purchase of for pesticides not included in the Authorized Pesticides List; and (c) payments made under category (6), unless Micro-Grants have been made in accordance with the provisions set
154  forth or referred to inthe Project Implementation Planandthe provisions o fparagraph 13 o f Schedule 4 of the Development Credit Agreement.
Project account - This account will be opened in a commercial bank acceptable to IDA. Counterpart funds will be deposited regularly in this account in accordance with project needs. To facilitate disbursements for eligible expenditures for goods, works and services, upon project effectiveness, the government would be required to make a deposit into the project account of CFAF30,000,000 covering an estimated six months o f eligible expenditures co-financed by the government.
ProcurementArrangements Fiduciary aspects will be managed by the PIU o f the Capacity Building & Economic Management Project (CBEMP).
Implementation Arrangements Procurement would be managed by the PIU o f the Capacity Building& Economic Management Project (CBEMP), which already have procurement specialist in its team with good experience and qualification in procurement. To prevent heavy workloads during some implementation phases, a short term consultant will be hired as needed.
Documents related to procurement below the prior review thresholds will be maintained by the Borrower for ex-post review by auditors and IDA supervision missions.
The PIU of the CBEMP will work closely with the Coordinator o f the Project located at the Secretary o f State for Agriculture.
Under project coordinator's supervision, the CBEMP will also be responsible for reporting on Project progress, financial management, procurement and disbursement, identifying implementation gaps and bottlenecks, and managingProject accounts andbudget.
Procedures Manual - The financial and administrative manual in use by the CBEMP will be adapted as needed inorder to respond to the specificity of the Locust Project.
Procurementpackagepreparation - All procurement packages will be prepared by the Procurement Specialist inthe PIU o f CBEMP.All procurementwill be carried out inaccordance with the procurement plan and as agreed with the Bank.
Summary of Assessment of theAgency's Capacity to Implement Procurement The procurement capacity assessment o f the Procurement Specialist o f the CBEMP shows a sufficient procurement capacity to handle the new project procurement in accordance with the World Bank procedures, since he has been working with procurement in IDA'S environment for three years and has attended trainings in procurement. However, the support o f a short term consultant should be necessary in order to reduce the heavy workload that could arise.
