156  Financial Management Arrangements Staffing The accounting unit of the CBEMP will be in charge o f the implementation o f the project.
The project will then benefit from their experience on managing IDA funds. The accounting unit of CBEMP i s comprised o f a Financial Comptroller (FC) and an assistant.
The FC has, as far as financial management is concerned, the responsibility to collect and control invoices, manage the project's bank accounts, keep the books o f accounts and prepare the financial reports.
The FC, inconjunction with the Loan Officer at the Department o f State for Finance and Economic Affairs (DoSFEA), will manage the special account o f the project. All the supporting documentationjustifyingthe use o f hnds will be prepared andkept by the FC o f CBEMP.
Giventhe workload, there is a need to strengthen the system by recruiting an accountant who will be incharge of maintaining the books, entering data inthe system and preparing all the accounting information under the supervision o fthe FC. Moreover it has been agreed that this will be transitional arrangement : the Bank is preparing a CDD project in The Gambia. This CDD project will handle all the fiduciary tasks o f this project as soon as it will be effective.
Accounting policies and Procedures A procedures manual will be developed and will provide all the required details on accounting and financial procedures. It will set out in particular the flow o f accounting and financial information between the accounting unit o f CBEMP and the beneficiaries, namely: Department of Agricultural Services, National Agricultural Research Institute, National Environment Agency, Department o f Planning, Department o f Health Services, The Gambia College, Non Governmental Organizations and the Department o f Cooperatives as well as the modalities and formats o f periodic reports. An overview of fimding flows and cash management mechanisms is provided in the paragraph on disbursements.
In terms of budgets, each year the beneficiaries will draw up a detailed budget for activities to be carried out. This budget will be consolidated by the accounting unit of CBEMP and after its validation by the project Coordinator in a meeting o f the management committee, will be submittedto the World Bank for review and then to the steering committee for approval.
Reporting and Monitoring The beneficiaries will be responsible o f the technical execution o f the activities. They will submit all the documents to the accounting unit of CBEMP for review andpayments.
157  They will also be responsible o f the procurement process. The procurement specialist o f CBEMP will review the quality o fthe documents before payments.
A monthly activity report will be producedbythe FC o f CBEMP with the support o fthe beneficiaries. This report will, in particular, summarize the status o f financial and technical execution and the volume o f procurement for the month ended, and will also contain forecasts.
The Project Coordinator will prepare and furnish to the Bank a Financial Monitoring Report (FMR), inform and substance satisfactory to the Bank,which:
Sets forth sources and uses o f funds for the Project, bothcumulatively and for the period covered by said report, showing separately funds provided under the Credit, and explains variances betweenthe actual and planned uses o f such funds; Describes physical progress inProject implementation, both cumulatively and for the period covered by said report, and explains variances between the actual and plannedProject implementation; and Sets forth the status o fprocurement under the Project, as at the end o fthe period covered by said report.
The first FMR shall be furnished to the Bank not later than 45 days after the end o f the first calendar quarter after the Effective Date, and shall cover the period from the incurrence o f the first expenditure under the Project through the end o f such first calendar quarter; thereafter, each FMR shall be furnished to the Bank not later than 45 days after each subsequentcalendar quarter, and shall cover such calendar quarter. Inthe areaofreporting, the Project Coordinator will also berequiredto produce, no later than June 30 o f the following fiscal year, audited annual financial statements. These financial statements will be subject to periodic audits (see paragraph on audits). Formats for the FMRs and financial statements will be defined in the procedures manual. The format o f the FMRswill be confirmed duringnegotiations.
Accounting software A sound computerizedinformation system is already established at PSAOP. The computerized information system will be updated in such a way as to furnish all o f the above data, in addition to providing analytical accounting for purposes o f monitoring beneficiaries, andparticularly ex-combatants and target groups.
External Audit An annual audit o f the project will be conducted by external auditors with qualifications andexperience satisfactory to the Bank. This audit will, on the one hand, be o f normal scope interms o f providing an opinion on annual financial statements, and its scope will also be broadened to cover the specific activities o f component related to the Grant to farmers. The auditor will be required to ensure that the grant payment procedures described in the procedures manual have been observed and that the duly identified beneficiaries have received the funds to which they are entitled. The auditor will express a special opinion on this point.

doc.repnme: Burkina Faso, Chad, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, and The Gambia - Africa Emergency Locust Project
doc.abstracts: This is the technical annex to the memorandum seeking approval to extend an Emergency Recovery Credit (ERC) to Burkina Faso, Chad, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, and The Gambia. The Africa Emergency Locust Project (AELP) will provide emergency assistance to seven countries to deal with the current infestation of desert locusts and its impact on the livelihood of millions of rural people living within those countries. In the short-term, the project will finance goods and operating costs for emergency locust control efforts. During this same period it will also finance income-generating activities as well as agriculture and livestock investments for those communities that have lost their assets as a result of the infestation. In the medium-term, the project will strengthen the capacity of government crop protection agencies to manage a possible resurgence of the infestation in the period from 2005 through 2007. Finally, the project will also support the countries ' participation in international collaborative efforts to prevent a re-occurrence of this natural disaster. The four project components address emergency locust management including launching a campaign and detailing inventories of pesticides; emergency agriculture investments including starter packs and animal feed to rural populations, and job creation, early warning and response consisting of building the capacity of crop protection agencies, financing equipment and software, and mobilizing village brigades; and project management.
